NTCIP_1218: NTCIP 1218

ID Description Discussion Links
NTCIP_1218-1

1 General [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-2

1.1 Scope
NTCIP_1218-3

NTCIP 1218 specifies the logical interface between an RSU and the controlling management stations. NTCIP 1218 defines information that may be exchanged across this interface. NTCIP 1218 first identifies the relevant RSU users and their needs, defines requirements that enable information exchanges that supports those needs, and finally defines the data objects and meta-data, including the relative structure of that data, necessary to meet these requirements.
NTCIP_1218-4

Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C-ITS) is a surface transportation environment where connected devices, such as vehicles or mobile devices (e.g., smartphones) interact or "talk" directly with each other, and the road infrastructure (which may or may not be owned by an agency). Known as connected vehicles in the United States, this environment could dramatically reduce the number of fatalities and injuries on the roadways, while improving mobility and environmental impacts.
NTCIP_1218-5

The roadside unit (RSU) is a key enabling component of the C-ITS environment; it serves as an interface, also known as a vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) interface, between connected devices and the roadway infrastructure. The U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC), at 47 CFR Part 90 (90.7), defines an RSU as:
NTCIP_1218-6

"…a DSRC transceiver that is mounted along a road or pedestrian passageway. An RSU may also be mounted on a vehicle or is hand carried, but it may only operate when the vehicle or handcarried unit is stationary. Furthermore, an RSU operating under this part is restricted to the location where it is licensed to operate. However, portable or hand-held RSUs are permitted to operate where they do not interfere with a site licensed operation. An RSU broadcasts data to OBUs [On-Board Units] or exchanges data with OBUs in its communications zone. An RSU also provides channel assignments and operating instructions to OBUs in its communications zone, when required."
NTCIP_1218-7

And an On-Board Unit (OBU) as,
NTCIP_1218-8

"…a DSRC transceiver that is normally mounted in or on a vehicle, or which in some instances may be a portable unit. An OBU can be operational while a vehicle or person is either mobile or stationary. The OBUs receive and contend for time to transmit on one or more radio frequency (RF) channels. Except where specifically excluded, OBU operation is permitted wherever vehicle operation or human passage is permitted. The OBUs mounted in vehicles are licensed by rule under part 95 of this chapter and communicate with Roadside Units (RSUs) and other OBUs. Portable OBUs are also licensed by rule under part 95 of this chapter. OBU operations in the Unlicensed National Information Infrastructure (UNII) Bands follow the rules in those bands."
NTCIP_1218-9

Although the FCC defined an RSU and an OBU as DSRC transceivers, NTCIP 1218 is agnostic on the form of the communications media among the connected devices and road infrastructure. NTCIP 1218 focuses on the well-known and well-understood communications media that were suitable for its intended purpose at the time, but is written to not preclude any future communications media. As such, the transceivers to interface with connected devices are called V2X transceivers throughout NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-10

Prior to the development of NTCIP 1218, there was no NTCIP standard fully defining how RSUs interface with management stations. As a result, proprietary (manufacturer-specific) protocols were developed. The resulting RSUs and RSU systems are not interchangeable or interoperable, and that can seriously limit the seamless operations along an arterial corridor across multiple jurisdictions. If an agency wishes to use either a central management system or additional RSUs from a different manufacturer, the agency encounters significant systems integration challenges, requiring additional resources to address. These additional resource requirements inhibit information sharing within and between various potential users of the data and prevent manufacturer interoperability from a common remote monitoring and management platform/system. Without manufacturer interoperability, resource requirements further increase because of a lack of a competitive market.
NTCIP_1218-11

Such challenges are not unique to RSUs. Many other roadway devices, such as traffic signal controllers, dynamic message signs, bus priority sensors, weather and environmental monitoring, and others, also need to exchange information with management systems.
NTCIP_1218-12

To address these challenges, NTCIP is a family of open standards for communications between field devices and central management systems. NTCIP 1218 is part of that larger family and defines an interoperable and interchangeable interface between a transportation management system and an RSU, while still allowing for extensions beyond NTCIP 1218 to allow for new functions as needed. This approach is expected to support the deployment of RSUs from one or more manufacturers in a consistent and resource-efficient way.
NTCIP_1218-13

NTCIP 1218 standardizes the communications interface by identifying operational needs of the users (Section 2) and subsequently identifying the necessary requirements (Section 3) that support each need. NTCIP 1218 then defines the NTCIP standardized communications interface used to fulfill these requirements by identifying the dialogs (Section 4) and related data concepts (Section 5) that support each requirement. Traceability among the various sections is defined by the Protocol Requirements List (Section 3.3) and the Requirements Traceability Matrix (Annex A). Conformance requirements for NTCIP 1218 are provided in Section 3.3. NTCIP 1218 only addresses a subset of the requirements needed for procurement.
NTCIP_1218-14

NTCIP 1218 does not address requirements related to the performance of the V2X radio, hardware components, mounting details, etc. NTCIP 1218 also does not address requirements that relate to configure or manage applications that run on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-15

1.2 References
NTCIP_1218-16

1.2.1 Normative References
NTCIP_1218-17

Normative references contain provisions that, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of NTCIP 1218 v01A. Other references in NTCIP 1218 v01A might provide a complete understanding or provide additional information. At the time of publication, the editions indicated were valid. All standards are subject to revision, and parties to agreements based on NTCIP 1218 v01A are encouraged to investigate the possibility of applying the most recent editions of the standards listed.

1.2.2 Other References
NTCIP_1218-64

The following documents and standards may provide the reader with a more complete understanding of the entire protocol and the relations between all parts of the protocol. However, these documents do not contain direct provisions that are required by NTCIP 1218 v01A. At the time of publication, the editions indicated were valid. All standards are subject to revision, and parties to agreements based on NTCIP 1218 v01A are encouraged to investigate the possibility of applying the most recent editions of the standard listed.

NTCIP_1218-141

1.3 General Statements
2024-10-16: Kenneth Vaughn

Added general statements
NTCIP_1218-142

1.3.1 SNMPv3

The information defined in this document can theoretically be exchanged over any communications stack, but is designed to be exchanged using SNMPv3. Within the context of this document SNMPv3 refers to a complete communications stack, as described in NTCIP 2301 v03 and ISO 15784-2:2024, which (among other requirements) require support for Transport Layer Security (TLS) version 1.3 and the TLS Transport Model (TLSTM). TLSTM defines how the SNMP engine uses the TLS certificate to manage SNMP data access.
NTCIP_1218-1995

1.3.2 Use of SMIv2

SNMPv3 is designed to exchange data defined using the Structure of Management Information (SMI) Version 2 (v2) as defined in RFC 2578. The data definitions also conform with NTCIP 8004, which defines additional rules (e.g., the subclauses used within the DESCRIPTION clause. This document updates the MIB to conform to the current version of NTCIP 8004 while retaining the object identifiers of previously declared object types. In some cases, minor revisions have been made to objects; when these have any technical impact, the issue is identified in the Informative subclause of the object type description and in the object refinement table in Annex A, when necessary.
NTCIP_1218-1996

1.3.3 Presentation of MIB and References

This document contains a MIB as well as references to elements defined within the MIB. This document uses the Courier New font to distinguish this text from normal English text.
NTCIP_1218-1997

1.3.4 Superseding and Supplanting Objects

Many of the object types defined in this document identify superseding or supplanting object types by using a "<Superseded by>" or "<Supplanted by>" clause. Supplanting object type(s) provide similar functionality while superseding objects provide a new interface for the same device capability.

For example, eventConfigMode (defined in NTCIP 1103 v03) is supplanted with fdCondTriggerMode (defined in ISO 26048-1). Although both objects provide similar functionality (i.e., identifying a type of condition to trigger an event), setting an instance of eventConfigMode does not affect any instance of fdCondTriggerMode in an implementation that supports both objects because the associated event logs are defined separately. 

By contrast, globalTime (defined in NTCIP 1201 v03) is superseded by fdClockUtcDate and fdClockUtcTime. In other words, if a device supports both globalTime and fdClockUtcTime, setting globalTime will affect the time reported by fdClockUtcTime. The core device capability is the same (e.g., keeping time), but there is a new interface that provides greater range and resolution.
NTCIP_1218-1998

1.3.5 PSID Values

All PSID values referenced in this document and used within a device conforming to this document shall be interpreted according to the IEEE Provider Service Identifier (PSID) Public Listing.
2024-10-16: Kenneth Vaughn

Revised to reference the Public Listing rather than the RA
NTCIP_1218-143

1.4 Terms
NTCIP_1218-144

For the purposes of NTCIP 1218, the following terms, definitions, acronyms, and abbreviations apply. Electrical and electronic terms not defined here are used in accordance with their definitions in IEEE Std 100-2000. English words not defined here or in IEEE Std 100-2000 are used in accordance with their definitions in Webster’s New Collegiate Dictionary.
NTCIP_1218-145

1.4.1 Term

Definition
NTCIP_1218-146

1.4.2 Connected Device

A mobile device, such as a vehicle, smartphone or infrastructure safety device, equipped to transmit or receive data using Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC)/ IEEE 802.11, 3GPP or other wireless communications.
NTCIP_1218-147

1.4.3 Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)

UTC is the time standard commonly used across the world. The world’s timing centers have agreed to keep their time scales closely synchronized – or coordinated. This 24-hour time standard is kept using highly precise atomic clocks combined with the Earth’s rotation. UTC is similar to Greenwich Mean Time, but while UTC is a time standard, GMT refers to a time zone (similar to Eastern Standard Time). UTC never changes to account for daylight savings time.

Note: UTC may have different references. RSU 4.1 Spec is based on 1/1/1970 while IEEE 1609.2 security is based on 1/1/2004 and needs to adjust for leap-year seconds.
NTCIP_1218-149

1.4.4 Dedicated Short Range Communications

A V2X communications interface compliant with IEEE 802.11p.
NTCIP_1218-150

1.4.5 Interchangeability

A condition which exists when two or more items possess such functional and physical characteristics as to be equivalent in performance and durability, and are capable of being exchanged one for the other without alteration of the items themselves, or adjoining items, except for adjustment, and without selection for fit and performance. (National Telecommunications and Information Administration, U.S. Department of Commerce).                                                   
NTCIP_1218-151

1.4.6 Interoperability

The ability of two or more systems or components to exchange information and use the information that has been exchanged (IEEE Std. 610.12-1990.

Note: From IEEE Standard Glossary of Software Engineering Terminology.
NTCIP_1218-153

1.4.7 Management Station

The computer system with which the device communicates. Typically, the management station commands and monitors the device.
NTCIP_1218-154

1.4.8 On-Board Unit (OBU)

A mobile device used to wirelessly communicate with other devices for safety and mobility purposes. Typically installed in a vehicle but may be on a pedestrian or a work zone worker.
NTCIP_1218-155

1.4.9 PC5

A V2X communications interface compliant with 3GPP R14 PC5 mode 4.
NTCIP_1218-156

1.4.10 Provider Service Identifiers

A globally unique integer value that is associated with a service being provided using a communications system such as 5.9 GHz WAVE.

Source: IEEE 1609.2
NTCIP_1218-158

1.4.11 Roadside Unit (RSU)

Devices that serve as the demarcation component between vehicles and other mobile devices and existing traffic equipment.

Note: From RSU 4.1 Spec. Also referenced as Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment (CV RSE) in ARC-IT.
NTCIP_1218-160

1.4.12 Security Profile

A means for specifying options and parameters that are provided to the 1609.2 security services by a particular consumer of those services. May be used as part of the specification of a secure data exchange entity.

Source: IEEE 1609.2
NTCIP_1218-162

1.4.13 V2X Interface

A logical component of the RSU representing the wireless interface between the RSU and connected devices, such as connected vehicles.

Note: While RSU connection to roadway users is wireless, some RSUs may connect to infrastructure via wire.
NTCIP_1218-164

1.5 Abbreviations
NTCIP_1218-165

NTCIP_1218-166

NTCIP_1218-220

2 Concept of Operations [Normative]
NTCIP_1218-221

Section 2 defines the user needs that subsequent sections within NTCIP 1218 address. Accepted system engineering processes detail that requirements should only be developed to fulfill well-defined user needs. The first stage in this process is to identify the ways in which the system is intended to be used. In the case of NTCIP 1218, this entails identifying the various ways in which transportation managers or transportation operators may use RSU information to fulfill their duties.
NTCIP_1218-222

This concept of operations provides the reader with the following:
NTCIP_1218-1414

A detailed description of the scope of NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-1415

An explanation of how an RSU is expected to fit into the larger context of an ITS network.
NTCIP_1218-1416

A starting point in the agency procurement process.
NTCIP_1218-1417

An understanding of the perspective of the designers of NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-223

Section 2 is intended for all readers and users of NTCIP 1218, including the following:
NTCIP_1218-224

Transportation Managers:  Agency personnel responsible for making decisions about operational strategies to implement and configuring transportation field devices.
NTCIP_1218-1418

Transportation Operators: Agency personnel responsible for monitoring the transportation infrastructure and implementing transportation strategies.
NTCIP_1218-1419

Transportation Engineers:  Agency personnel responsible for planning or designing the transportation infrastructure.
NTCIP_1218-1420

Maintenance Personnel:  Agency personnel responsible for ensuring that transportation field devices operate as intended.
NTCIP_1218-225

System Integrators:  Entities that bring together different components or subsystems into a whole system that functions together.
NTCIP_1218-1421

Device Manufacturers: Vendors providing transportation field devices. May also include vendors providing central systems to configure, monitor and control these field devices.
NTCIP_1218-1422

Application Developers: Vendors providing applications that run on transportation field devices or custom applications that run from a central server, cloud service, or back-office location.
NTCIP_1218-226

For the first four categories of readers, Section 2 is useful to understand how RSU equipment can be used in their system. For this audience, Section 2 serves as the starting point in the procurement process and enables these readers to become familiar with each feature supported by NTCIP 1218 and determine whether that feature is appropriate for their implementation. If appropriate, then the procurement specification requires support for the feature and all mandatory requirements related to that feature.
NTCIP_1218-227

For the last three categories of readers, Section 2 provides a more thorough understanding as to why the more detailed requirements exist later in NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-228

2.1 Tutorial [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-229

A concept of operations describes a proposed system from the users' perspective. Typically, a concept of operations is used on a project to ensure that system developers understand users' needs. Within the context of NTCIP standards, a concept of operations documents the intent of each feature for which NTCIP 1218 supports a communications interface. It also serves as the starting point for users to select which features may be appropriate for their project.
NTCIP_1218-230

The concept of operations starts with a discussion of the current situation and issues that have led to the need to deploy systems covered by the scope of NTCIP 1218 and to the development of NTCIP 1218 itself. This discussion is presented in layman's terms such that both the potential users of the system and the system developers can understand and appreciate the situation.
NTCIP_1218-231

The concept of operations then documents key aspects about the proposed system, including the following:
NTCIP_1218-1423

Reference Physical Architecture: The reference physical architecture (view) defines the overall context of the proposed system and defines which specific interfaces are addressed by NTCIP 1218. The reference physical architecture is supplemented with one or more samples that describe how the reference physical architecture may be realized in an actual deployment.
NTCIP_1218-1424

Architectural Needs: The architectural needs section discusses the issues and needs relative to the system architecture that have a direct impact on NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-1425

Features: The features identify and describe the various functions that users may want components of an RSU system to perform. These features are derived from the high-level user needs identified in the problem statement (Section 2.2) but are refined and organized into a more manageable structure that forms the basis of the traceability tables contained in Section 3 and Annex A.
NTCIP_1218-232

The architectural needs and features are collectively called user needs. Section 3 uses these user needs in the analysis of the system to define the various functional requirements of an RSU. Each user need traces to one or more functional requirements, and each functional requirement is derived from at least one user need. This traceability is shown in the Protocol Requirements List (PRL) in Section 3.3.
NTCIP_1218-233

While NTCIP 1218 is intended to standardize communications across a wide range of deployments, it is not intended to mandate support for every feature for every deployment. Therefore, the PRL also defines each user need and requirement as mandatory, optional, or conditional. The only items marked mandatory are those that relate to the most basic functionality of a roadside unit. To procure a roadside unit that meets specific needs, the user first identifies which optional needs are necessary for the specific project.
NTCIP_1218-234

Each requirement identified is then presented in the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) in Annex A, which defines how the requirement is fulfilled through standardized dialogs and data element definitions provided in Section 4 and Section 5.
NTCIP_1218-235

A conformant device may support other user needs, as long as these are conformant with the requirements of NTCIP 1218 and its normative references (see Section 1.2.1). For example, a device may support data that has not been defined by NTCIP 1218 v01; however, when exchanged via an SNMP-like protocol, the data shall be properly registered with a valid OBJECT IDENTIFIER under the Global ISO Naming Tree.
NTCIP_1218-236

Note: Off-the-shelf interoperability and interchangeability can only be obtained by using well-documented user needs, along with their corresponding requirements and design, that are broadly supported by the industry as a whole. Designing a system that uses environments or features not defined in a standard or not typically deployed in combination with one another inhibits the goals of interoperability and interchangeability, especially if the documentation of these user needs is not available for distribution to system integrators. NTCIP 1218 v01 allows implementations to support additional user needs to support innovation, which is constantly needed within the industry, but users should be aware of the risks involved with using such environments or features.
NTCIP_1218-237

The concept of operations concludes by describing the security needs for NTCIP 1218 and by providing a description of how NTCIP 1218 relates to the Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT) (formerly the National ITS Architecture and the Connected Vehicle Reference Implementation Architecture).
NTCIP_1218-238

2.2 Current Situation and Problem Statement [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-239

The Cooperative-ITS (C-ITS) environment, also known as connected vehicles, started as a research program led by USDOT to investigate how transportation connectivity potentially enables applications to improve the United State’s transportation system in the areas of safety, mobility, and the environment. Transportation connectivity can take place between vehicles (vehicle-to-vehicle, V2V) to enable crash prevention; between vehicles and the infrastructure (vehicle-to-infrastructure, V2I) to enable additional safety, mobility and environmental benefits; between personal devices and the infrastructure (personal-to-infrastructure, P2I) to enable safety and mobility benefits; and among vehicles, infrastructure and personal devices (vehicle-to-everything, V2X) to provide continuous real-time connectivity.
NTCIP_1218-240

The RSU is a key component of the C-ITS environment. The RSU provides an interface: 1) between a traffic management center (TMC) and a connected device (including connected vehicles); and 2) between connected devices and other ITS roadside devices (e.g., a traffic signal controller) through a managed network. The RSU allows transportation managers to exchange information between connected devices and the infrastructure (traffic management centers and ITS roadside devices), collecting data from one component and forwarding that same data to another component. Through this data exchange, managers and applications can use this data to:
NTCIP_1218-1426

Improve surface transportation safety by better controlling traffic operations on the roadway and providing directed warnings to travelers.
NTCIP_1218-1427

Improve mobility by optimizing traffic operations and through warnings and advisories to travelers.
NTCIP_1218-1428

Improve the environment by more efficiently managing traffic operations to reduce delays, fuel consumption and emissions.
NTCIP_1218-241

While a number of standards define V2V and V2I interfaces, prior to NTCIP 1218, no standard defines the center to RSU interface. As the C-ITS environment is deployed, it becomes increasingly important to develop a standard to interface with and manage the RSU from a TMC instead of using proprietary communications protocols.
NTCIP_1218-242

The lack of such a standard results in several RSU deployment challenges. Device interoperability and consistent device monitoring and management are examples of such challenges. Despite the development of the DSRC Roadside Unit (RSU) Specifications Document v4.1 (RSU 4.1 Spec) sponsored by USDOT, the RSU 4.1 Spec has not been implemented consistently for conformance, therefore not guaranteeing interoperability. The RSU 4.1 Spec also provides no guidance for extensions to support needed capabilities (beyond those functions defined in RSU 4.1 Spec).
NTCIP_1218-243

Comparing existing RSU deployments, different architectures have been designed for the RSU system, and different standards or methods have been used for exchanging data, such as uploading applications, across the center and RSU interface.
NTCIP_1218-244

These inconsistent deployments create barriers for transportation managers at agencies to easily deploy and manage RSU devices.
NTCIP_1218-245

2.3 Reference Physical Architecture [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-246

Section 2.3 represents an overview of what a complete RSU system may look like for a transportation agency and identifies the specific information exchange paths to be addressed by NTCIP 1218 and related standards. Figure 1 presents a graphical depiction of the physical architecture around an RSU system.
NTCIP_1218-247
NTCIP_1218-247_1_image001.png
NTCIP_1218-249

The RSU system is a collection of devices, including the following:
NTCIP_1218-1429

Roadside Unit (RSU): A field device that supports secure communications with connected devices and may include a computing platform running applications. The RSU exchanges data among nearby connected devices (vehicles or mobile devices), other ITS Roadside Devices, and management systems at centers (such as a Traffic Management Center (TMC) or a Connected Vehicle Back Office System). In this context, the RSU is a NTCIP device.
NTCIP_1218-1430

ITS Roadside Devices: A host computing platform that may manage roadway control devices (e.g., lane control signs) or collect and forward sensor data from roadway devices (such as roadway weather sensors or vehicle detectors).
NTCIP_1218-1431

Traffic Management System: A management station typically located in some type of management center (e.g., a Traffic Management Center) and may be physically located at a considerable distance away from the RSU. A management station in this context is a host computing platform that manages one or more NTCIP field devices, such as an RSU. The management station is responsible for configuring, monitoring, and controlling the RSU. There may be multiple management stations for a given RSU. A “manager” is a transportation system manager (or maintenance personnel), who needs to access information in the RSU through the management station.
NTCIP_1218-1432

Maintenance Laptop: A computer that maintenance personnel (such as a field technician) may use on a trip to visit the RSU or a field processor that may be used to access the RSU. It typically acts as an on-site management station for the RSU, capable of configuring, monitoring, and controlling the RSU. It typically plugs directly into the RSU and is commonly used to monitor the data reported from the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-250

Connected Devices: A mobile device, such as a vehicle with an OBU, smartphone, or infrastructure, equipped to exchange data using wireless communications.
NTCIP_1218-1433

Cooperative-ITS (C-ITS) Back Office Systems: Represent computer systems that supports the C-ITS environment, including security services.
NTCIP_1218-1434

Traffic Signal Controller: A type of ITS Roadside Device.
NTCIP_1218-251

2.3.1 RSU Characteristics - General
NTCIP_1218-252

NTCIP 1218 addresses the communications interface between a management station and an RSU. USDOT's RSU 4.1 Spec defines:
NTCIP_1218-253

"The purpose of the RSU is to facilitate communication between transportation infrastructure and vehicles and other mobile devices by exchanging data over DSRC in compliance with industry standards, including but not limited to (IEEE 802.11, IEEE 1609.x, SAE J2735, and SAE J2945). Additionally, the RSU can be integrated with a backhaul system to enable remote management and provide vehicles and other mobile devices with services and applications delivered by back office service providers."
NTCIP_1218-254

The United States Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT) also implies a logical framework of applications and services that are allocated to the RSU. Based on these definitions and through discussions with stakeholders, an RSU system can be viewed as three logical components, as shown by the blue circles in Figure 2.
NTCIP_1218-255
NTCIP_1218-255_1_image002.png
NTCIP_1218-257

The first component is the Wireless Interface, also called the V2X Interface in this standard, which is the wireless interface for communicating with vehicles and connected devices. Although the RSU 4.1 Spec assumes the wireless radio to conform to standards such as IEEE 802.11 and IEEE 1609.x standard, NTCIP 1218 strives to be technology-neutral. This allows NTCIP 1218 to support potential future wireless technologies while maintaining support for the other components of an RSU.
NTCIP_1218-258

The second component is the Network Interface. The RSU serves as a demarcation component among vehicles and other connected devices through the Wireless interface, other ITS roadside devices (such as traffic signal controllers, environmental sensor stations, or dynamic message signs), and center systems such as a traffic management system. As a network interface, the RSU facilitates communications among these devices and systems.
NTCIP_1218-259

Note: The Wireless Interface and the Network Interface comprise the Message Handling Process defined in NTCIP 1202 v04.
NTCIP_1218-260

The third component is the CV Applications Process, which is a logical process that serves as a computing platform for applications that provide services to travelers, infrastructure owner-operators, or other users in a C-ITS environment. This component uses inputs (from vehicles, connected devices, ITS roadside devices or traffic management systems) to provide these services. The CV Applications Process may also enable the security features, available from the C-ITS Back Office Systems for the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-261

Figure 2 also depicts the interfaces between the different components and devices that comprise the C-ITS environment around and including the RSU. The interface between the management station and the Wireless Interface, the Network Interface, and CV Applications Process are solid orange lines, which indicates these interfaces are addressed by NTCIP 1218 and the NTCIP family of standards. RSU configuration, monitoring, and control data are addressed by NTCIP 1218. In addition, signal phase and timing (SPaT) information between an ITS Roadside Device (specifically, a traffic signal controller) and the CV Applications Process are also addressed by NTCIP 1218. Management of other data, such as applications data beyond the operational environment of the RSU, is not in scope. Applications data include software applications or data collected and stored by software applications.
NTCIP_1218-262

The remaining interfaces are in black and are outside the scope of NTCIP 1218, although the data across those interfaces should be defined by one or more standards or industry specifications.
NTCIP_1218-263

From a physical point of view, two possible physical architectures are considered in NTCIP 1218, defined by where the CV Applications Process component is physically located. In the first architecture (Figure 2), the CV Applications Process is physically located within the same device as the Network Interface and the Wireless Interface. In the second architecture (Figure 3), the CV Applications Process, shown in maroon, is physically located in a separate computing device apart from the device with the Network Interface and Wireless Interface. The CV Applications Process can, for example, be physically located within the management station or the ITS Roadside Device.
NTCIP_1218-264
NTCIP_1218-264_1_image003.png
NTCIP_1218-266

It is also possible that the Wireless Interface and Network Interface are located in separate physical boxes, but that is not relevant in NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-267

2.3.2 RSU Characteristics - V2X Radio Type
NTCIP_1218-268

The previous section describes the first logical component that NTCIP 1218 is intended to address as the V2X Interface, which is the wireless interface for communicating with vehicles and connected devices. Although NTCIP 1218 strives to be technology-neutral, some requirements apply to specific communications technologies. The technologies addressed in NTCIP 1218 are the following:
NTCIP_1218-1435

DSRC Radio: Defined by IEEE 802.11 and the Federal Communications Commission.
NTCIP_1218-1436

PC5 Radio: Defined by ETSI TS 136 213, ETSI TS 136 321, and ETSI TS 136 322. PC5 is an interface for short range communications between devices. Also called LTE-V2X in NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-269

2.4 Architectural Needs
2024-08-07: Kenneth Vaughn

Replace with reference to ISO 26048-1 features as with other standards; determine which are appropriate for NTCIP 1218
NTCIP_1218-270

NTCIP 1218 addresses the interface between an RSU and one or more management stations (e.g., central computers, laptops, etc.). The management station may also need to retrieve data that has been collected by the RSU and manage applications on the RSU. After the management station has retrieved the data of interest, a manager can use the retrieved data to make decisions and initiate other events (such as changes to the traveler information messages) to better manage the transportation system.
NTCIP_1218-271

To fulfill these needs, the transportation system manager needs to establish a communication system that links the RSU with a management station. For some systems, the resources required for communications may be minimal; other systems may require significant resources for communicating with the RSU and as such, the system may be designed to minimize data exchanges. When deploying an RSU, the system designer needs to consider which of the following operational environments need to be supported.
NTCIP_1218-272

The RSU acts as an intermediary between the management station and the connected devices, such as OBUs. The RSU provides support functions in that role, such as firmware updates, data retrieval, and process management. The RSU also needs to support the exchange of data from connected devices for road network monitoring, safety, and other applications.
NTCIP_1218-273

An RSU is expected to operate in the communications environment defined as follows.
NTCIP_1218-274

2.4.1 Configure, Monitor, and Control the RSU
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-493 Retrieve Data
NTCIP_1218-495 Deliver Data
NTCIP_1218-497 Explore Data
NTCIP_1218-1106 Response Time for Requests
NTCIP_1218-275

A transportation manager and transportation operator need to retrieve data and control the RSU by issuing requests (e.g., requests to access information, alter information, or control the device). In this environment, the RSU responds to requests from the management station (e.g., through the provision of live data, success/failure notice of information alteration, or success/failure of the command).
NTCIP_1218-276

2.4.2 Provide for Log Data Local Storage and Retrieval
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-503 Close an Active Event Log File
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-501 Configure Priority Level for Events
NTCIP_1218-506 Retrieve Event Logged Data
NTCIP_1218-1106 Response Time for Requests
NTCIP_1218-1112 Event Log - System Events
NTCIP_1218-1116 Event Log - Application Events
NTCIP_1218-1120 Event Log - RSU Configuration
NTCIP_1218-1123 Event Log - Notification
NTCIP_1218-1125 Event Log - Security
NTCIP_1218-1127 Event Log - Stored Message
NTCIP_1218-1129 Event Log - Immediate Forward Message
NTCIP_1218-277

In a typical operational environment, a transportation operator needs logged data from the RSU for diagnostic purposes, and for operational environments (e.g., dial-up links) that do not have always-on connections. For example, logged data may include the time when the communications connectivity is broken.
NTCIP_1218-278

2.4.3 Condition-based Exception Reporting
2024-10-16: Kenneth Vaughn

Need to add support for acknowledgements (NTCIP-5)
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-508 Condition-based Exception Reporting
NTCIP_1218-279

In some operational environments, a transportation operator needs to have the RSU automatically transmit data to the management station when certain conditions occur. Under this scenario, a transportation manager can program the information to be automatically reported to the management station when a specified condition occurs. An example is a manager wants to know when an RSU enclosure door is opened, a power failure is detected, or an attempt to potentially hijack the device is detected; these conditions can be programmed to cause the transmission of the alarm objects thus providing the management station with information regarding the change of state at the RSU cabinet.
NTCIP_1218-2058

2.5 Architectural Needs
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

Added replacement clause; duplicated from NTCIP 1204, but we should discuss conformance for NTCIP 1218
NTCIP_1218-2059

2.5.1 ISO 26048-1 Needs Included

All the architectural needs are defined within the user needs of ISO 26048-1. Commonly used architectural needs within the scope of a ESS are listed in the PRL with references to the relevant ISO 26048-1 clauses and include the following:
NTCIP_1218-2060

2.5.1.1 Authenticate users

allows users to ensure that all communications with the device are with authenticated users.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-130 Authenticate users
NTCIP_1218-2061

2.5.1.2 Control access to data

allows administrators to configure the detailed access privileges that are granted to each authenticated user.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-131 Control access to data
NTCIP_1218-2062

2.5.1.3 Monitor failed access to the field device

allows administrators to discover when unauthorized attempts are made to access the device.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-132 Monitor failed access to the field devic…
NTCIP_1218-2063

2.5.1.4 Manage the field device

allows a user to remotely reset the controller and configure and monitor basic information about the field device, such as its:
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-133 Manage the field device
NTCIP_1218-2064

Identity,
NTCIP_1218-2065

Location,
NTCIP_1218-2066

Power source,
NTCIP_1218-2067

Default language,
NTCIP_1218-2068

Capabilities (e.g., which objects are supported, maximum message size),
NTCIP_1218-2069

Status, and
NTCIP_1218-2070

Configuration identifier.
NTCIP_1218-2071

2.5.1.5 Monitor field device components
NTCIP_1218-2072
2.5.1.5.1 Monitor field device enclosure

allows a user to monitor the device environment and enclosure(s), including:

allows a user to monitor and control power equipment, including:

allows a user to monitor and control support equipment, including:

2.5.1.5.4.1 Manage field device auxiliary bi-directional ports

26048-1-159 Manage field device auxiliary bi-directi…
NTCIP_1218-2092
2.5.1.5.4.2 Monitor field device auxiliary inputs
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-160 Monitor field device auxiliary inputs
NTCIP_1218-2093
2.5.1.5.4.3 Manage field device auxiliary outputs
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-161 Manage field device auxiliary outputs
NTCIP_1218-2094

2.5.1.6 Receive notification of triggers firing

allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically receive an SNMP notification when the trigger condition occurs.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-162 Receive notification of triggers firing
NTCIP_1218-2095

2.5.1.7 Manage device-specific notifications

allows the user to configure all supported notifications to use notification channels, which prevent notifications from flooding the communications channel.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-165 Manage device-specific notifications
NTCIP_1218-2096

2.5.1.8 Log system events

allows the device to record information about internal events that can be of interest during forensic analysis, e.g., for debugging purposes.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-166 Log system events
NTCIP_1218-2097

2.5.1.9 Log user-defined data snapshots

allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically log information when the trigger condition occurs.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-167 Log user-defined data snapshots
NTCIP_1218-2098

2.5.1.10 Issue trigger-based commands

allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically send another device an SNMP set request when the trigger condition occurs. For example, when ice is detected by a pavement sensor, command an attached gate to close (however, this example is discouraged as a gate closure should include verification mechanisms not offered by this feature to ensure safe operations).
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-172 Issue trigger-based commands
NTCIP_1218-2099

2.5.2 ISO 26048-1 Needs Omitted due to Duplication
NTCIP_1218-2100

2.5.2.1 Monitor ambient air temperature

The body of this document provides a more robust way to monitor ambient air temperature (2.5.2.1.3) that predates the design contained in ISO 26048-1.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-137 Monitor ambient air temperature
NTCIP_1218-2101

2.5.2.2 Monitor ambient relative humidity

The body of this document provides a more robust way to monitor ambient relative humidity (2.5.2.1.4) that predates the design contained in ISO 26048-1.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-138 Monitor ambient relative humidity
NTCIP_1218-2102

2.5.3 ISO 26048-1 Needs not Envisioned for ESS
NTCIP_1218-2103

2.5.3.1 Monitor ambient light

allows the device to measure ambient light levels (e.g., from the sun).
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-139 Monitor ambient light
NTCIP_1218-2104

2.5.3.2 Record a series of data snapshots

allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically log a series of snapshots based on the trigger condition occurring. For example, when the cabinet door opens, record the cabinet temperature once a second for 60 seconds.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-170 Record a series of data snapshots
NTCIP_1218-2105

2.5.3.3 Configure a complex device

allows a user to buffer changes to a large number of inter-related configuration parameters so that the proposed changes can be validated as a whole prior to ensure a safe configuration prior to implementation. 
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-175 Configure a complex device
NTCIP_1218-2106

2.5.3.4 Efficient exchange of data

allows a management station to define dynamic objects that can be used for frequent requests to reduce communications overhead. For example, rather than monitoring 15 discreet status objects, the 15 objects can be placed into a dynamic object and retrieved as a single entity. This can be useful when a management station frequently exchanges a large number of integer values with the device.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-177 Efficient exchange of data
NTCIP_1218-2107

2.5.4 Responsive Device

A transportation system operator needs the device to be responsive to conditions without causing unnecessary communication delays.
Conditionally met by:
Conditionals-90 Notifications
NTCIP_1218-280

2.6 Features
NTCIP_1218-1437

The features that may be offered by the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-281

2.6.1 Manage the RSU Configuration
NTCIP_1218-282

The features that allow a transportation manager to manage the configuration of the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-283

2.6.1.1 Manage the RSU Device
NTCIP_1218-284

The features that allow a transportation manager to manage the RSU device follow.
NTCIP_1218-285
2.6.1.1.1 Retrieve RSU Identity
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Everything except rsuID is addressed by ISO 26048-1. Component information is handled by the ENTITY-MIB (RFC 6933) ISO 26048-1, 8.8.2.1.6. Supported standards and MIB version are better addressed by sysORID (RFC 3418) required by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.7. System name is handled by the same object along with sysContact and sysLocation as a part of RFC 3418, as required by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.1, 8.5.2.3.

What is the intended difference between rsuID and sysName? NOTE: This user need alludes to an identifier "as provided by the manufacturer" however, both rsuID and sysName are read-write. However, RFC 6933 defines entPhysicalName that should satisfy this need.

Perhaps we delete this user need? Perhaps we need supplemental requirements to clearly define what "components" must have entries in the physical entity table?
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-518 Store RSU Identifier
NTCIP_1218-520 Report RSU Component Information
NTCIP_1218-524 Report RSU System Name
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-522 Report Supported Standards
NTCIP_1218-526 Report RSU MIB Version
NTCIP_1218-286

A transportation manager needs to request and obtain basic information about the RSU. This information consists of the make, model, and version of the device components. The device components can be a hardware, software, or firmware component, and could be a physical or logical entity in nature. This feature allows the manager to verify the identity of the RSU in the field and what software or firmware version is installed. This feature also allows the manager to retrieve a unique identifier of the RSU as provided by the RSU manufacturer, and the version of standards supported by the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-287
2.6.1.1.2 Retrieve Configuration Version of the RSU
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Deprecate and supersede with fdConfigurationID (8.5.2.14)
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-528 Report Deployment Configuration Identifi…
NTCIP_1218-288

A transportation manager needs to determine the version of the configuration parameters for the RSU. This feature allows a manager to determine if the RSU has the correct and expected values of the configuration parameters. The configuration version identifier changes whenever a value of a configurable parameter changes. For example, a manager can check the current version identifier of an RSU and if the value of the version identifier is different than expected by the manager, the difference indicates that configuration of the RSU has changed.
NTCIP_1218-289
2.6.1.1.3 Manage RSU Location Information
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Consider ISO 26048-1 location objects and how they relate. (e.g., fdConfiguredLatitude and fdGnssLatitude) and whether we want to submit any comments on this topic

2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

If we decide to keep, update the conditional links to conform to the required pattern
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-549 Report GNSS Data Output
NTCIP_1218-551 Store GNSS Data Output Interval
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-536 Store RSU Location
NTCIP_1218-947 Report RSU Location
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-534 Store RSU Location Description
NTCIP_1218-539 Store RSU Location - GNSS Antenna Offset
NTCIP_1218-541 Store V2X Antenna Offsets
NTCIP_1218-543 Report Positioning Augmentation
NTCIP_1218-547 Store GNSS Data Output Destination
NTCIP_1218-290

A transportation manager needs to configure a RSU's location (latitude, longitude, and elevation) information. This feature allows a manager to manually enter the reference location of the RSU, use the location as reported by an external subsystem, and determine the legitimacy of the subsystem used. This feature also allows a manager to configure the location of the antenna for the V2X Interface. The location information may be used for security purposes or used to compare with the location data of the devices that are connected to the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-291
2.6.1.1.4 Manage RSU Startup Functions
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Traces to Configure Startup Retries (3.5.1.1.4.4, O) and Retrieve Startup Retry Period (3.5.1.1.4.5, StartupFault:M) have been replaced with links to ISO 26048-1, 8.17.2.

Note added to explain that this is an extension to the base ISO 26048-1 functionality.
Conditionally met by:
Conditionals-91 Retrieve Startup Retry Period
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-555 Determine Maximum Number of Applications…
NTCIP_1218-557 Manage RSU Startup Functions - Applicati…
NTCIP_1218-1152 Copy Files using SCP
Optionally fulfilled by:
26048-1-833 Configure start-up retries
26048-1-834 Confirm start-up retries
NTCIP_1218-559 Manage RSU Startup Functions - Configura…
NTCIP_1218-292

A transportation manager needs to retrieve and configure the startup capabilities and functions of the RSU. This feature allows the manager to retrieve and configure user-definable parameters; not the manufacturer-defined parameters.
NTCIP_1218-2108

This is an extension to the base ISO 26048-1 functionality.
NTCIP_1218-293
2.6.1.1.5 Manage RSU Firmware Version
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Replaced trace to Report the RSU Firmware Version with ISO 26048-1, 8.8.2.1.6 with entPhysicalFirmwareVersion.
Fulfilled by:
26048-1-480 Confirm the field device's physical comp…

NTCIP_1218-571 Report Firmware Update Status
NTCIP_1218-1152 Copy Files using SCP
NTCIP_1218-294

A transportation manager needs to manage the firmware version of the RSU. This feature allows the manager to locally or remotely install new firmware updates on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-295
2.6.1.1.6 Manage Communications Loss
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-579 Configure Short-Term Communications Even…
NTCIP_1218-581 Configure Long-Term Communications Event…

NTCIP_1218-587 Configure Long-Term Communications Event…
Includes option groups:
NTCIP_1218-575 Configure Short-Term Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-577 Configure Long-Term Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-296

A transportation manager needs to configure the functionality and behavior of an RSU when backhaul communications with the traffic management center is lost.
NTCIP_1218-297
2.6.1.1.7 Manage Notifications
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Revise to either 

  1. Trace to ISO 26048-1, 6.6: Receive notification of triggers firing and make the NOTIFICATION-TYPEs obsolete (i.e., rely upon conditional triggers to monitor the data objects for onChange events); or 
  2. Trace to ISO 26048-1, 6.7: Manage device-specific notifications (and keep the independent NOTIFICATION-TYPEs)

This will ensure that the notifications are properly managed with other notifications.

Delete the traces to 3.5.1.1.7.1, 3.5.1.1.7.2, 3.5.1.1.7.4, 3.5.1.1.7.5, and 3.5.1.1.7.6
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-631 Store Notification Repeat Intervals
NTCIP_1218-633 Store Notification Retries
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-591 Store Notification Destination Address
NTCIP_1218-593 Store Notification Destination Port
NTCIP_1218-597 Notification - Integrity Check Error - A…
NTCIP_1218-599 Notification - Integrity Check Error - S…
NTCIP_1218-601 Notification - Authorization Verificatio…
NTCIP_1218-603 Notification - Signature Verification Er…
NTCIP_1218-605 Notification - Network Access Control Li…
NTCIP_1218-607 Notification - Time Source Loss
NTCIP_1218-609 Notification - Time Source Mismatch
NTCIP_1218-611 Notification - GNSS Anomaly
NTCIP_1218-613 Notification - GNSS Location Deviation
NTCIP_1218-615 Notification - Certificate Management
NTCIP_1218-627 Notification - Authentication Failure
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-617 Notification - Denial of Service
NTCIP_1218-619 Notification - Watchdog
NTCIP_1218-621 Notification - GNSS Data
NTCIP_1218-623 Notification - Configure GNSS Data Inter…
NTCIP_1218-625 Notification - Environmental
NTCIP_1218-629 Store Notification Type
NTCIP_1218-298

A transportation manager needs to configure the target network addresses and port number that an RSU transmits notifications to when a configured event occurs. This feature also allows a manager to assign a priority level to different notifications.
NTCIP_1218-299

2.6.1.2 Manage Network Interface
NTCIP_1218-300

The features that allow a transportation manager to manage network communications and data across the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-301
2.6.1.2.1 Manage a Network Interface
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-639 Enable/Disable a Communications Port
NTCIP_1218-641 Configure Ethernet Ports
NTCIP_1218-643 Report Ethernet Port - MAC Address
NTCIP_1218-302

A transportation manager needs to configure a network interface for an RSU. This feature consists of enabling or disabling the communications ports, configuring the port address (e.g., IP address), and configuring security, including access controls (e.g., which application entities are accessible from the physical port). Network interfaces might support one or more protocols, including IPv4, IPv6 or WSMP. This feature allows a manager to disable an unused communications port for security purposes or restrict access (e.g., to SNMP commands) from non-defined physical ports.
NTCIP_1218-303
2.6.1.2.2 Manage Messages
NTCIP_1218-304

The features related to managing messages received and sent by the RSU follow. These features allow a manager to manage the data (or messages) received or sent by the RSU device. The actions defined by the manager upon receiving a message may be determined by the type of message or the network interface from which it is received.
NTCIP_1218-305
2.6.1.2.2.1 Manage Stored Messages
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

The traceability appears to be incorrect. It appears that 3.5.1.2.2.1.2 AND 3.5.1.2.2.1.5 were intended to be deprecated and replaced with 3.5.1.2.2.1.14, which is an IDENTICAL requirement to 3.5.1.2.2.1.2. 

Proposal: Delete 3.5.1.2.2.1.14 and note in 3.5.1.2.2.1.2 (i.e., keep original requirement and delete duplicate)

Move the 3.5.1.2.2.1.14 trace to 3.5.1.2.2.1.2

NOTE: the original 3.5.1.2.2.1.2 is already duplicated by 3.5.5.1.1 (i.e., with a clarification that it is per v01 design)

Move 3.5.1.1.2.2.1.5 to 3.5.5.1.6 and trace to backwards compatibility with v01 (mandatory)

2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

We address a maximum notReady time but we do not talk about a maximum notInServiceTime. We should either explicitly state that entries are allowed to be 'notInService' indefinitely (and get rid of the corresponding Enabled object) or specify the maximum notInService time
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-649 Determine Maximum Number of Stored Messa…
NTCIP_1218-654 Delete a Stored Message
NTCIP_1218-656 Enable/Disable the Transmission of a Sto…
NTCIP_1218-658 Store a Message Type [Deprecated]
NTCIP_1218-661 Store PSID for Application Data Exchange…
NTCIP_1218-690 Store a Message V2
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-663 Delete All Stored Messages
NTCIP_1218-306

A transportation manager needs to manage the messages stored on an RSU for transmission. Stored messages may be transmitted by the RSU during a configured time period. This feature allows a manager to view, edit, or delete stored messages. The stored message may already be signed.
NTCIP_1218-307
2.6.1.2.2.2 Manage Stored Messages for Transmission
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-661 Store PSID for Application Data Exchange…
NTCIP_1218-665 Store a Message's Priority
NTCIP_1218-667 Store a Message's Transmission Interval
NTCIP_1218-669 Store a Message's Transmission Channel
NTCIP_1218-684 Store a Message's Transmission Start Tim…
NTCIP_1218-686 Store a Message's Transmission Stop Time
NTCIP_1218-688 Store if a Message is to be Signed
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-663 Delete All Stored Messages
NTCIP_1218-308

A transportation manager needs to configure the parameters of when a stored message on an RSU is transmitted. This feature allows a manager to configure the network destination, the rate, the time period, transport protocol, priority level and the communications channel the message is transmitted by the RSU. This feature also allows a manager to associate the message with a specific service, and if the message should be signed or encrypted when transmitted. Messages may be signed before being provided to the RSU for transmission.
NTCIP_1218-309
2.6.1.2.2.3 Manage Received Messages for Forwarding to the V2X Interface
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-695 Determine Maximum Number of Immediate Fo…
NTCIP_1218-697 Forward Message to the V2X Interface
NTCIP_1218-699 Store the Message Type for a Message for…
NTCIP_1218-701 Store the PSID for an Application Data E…
NTCIP_1218-705 Store the Transmission Channel for a Mes…
NTCIP_1218-709 Store if a Received Message for Forwardi…
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-703 Store the Priority for a Message for For…
NTCIP_1218-310

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to forward messages received on a specific port number to the V2X interface. The configuration may be based on the type of message. This feature allows a manager to configure the transport protocol, priority level and the communications channel the message is forwarded by the RSU. This feature also allows a manager to associate the message with a specific service, and if the message should be signed or encrypted when forwarded.
NTCIP_1218-311
2.6.1.2.2.4 Manage Received Messages from the V2X Interface for Forwarding
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-713 Determine Maximum Number of Message Rece…
NTCIP_1218-715 Store Network Destination to Forward Mes…
NTCIP_1218-723 Store Start Time to Forward Messages Rec…
NTCIP_1218-725 Store Stop Time to Forward Messages Rece…
NTCIP_1218-727 Enable/Disable Forwarding Messages Recei…
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-717 Store Transport Protocol to Forward Mess…
NTCIP_1218-719 Store Minimum Signal Strength to Forward…
NTCIP_1218-721 Store Message Interval to Forward Messag…
NTCIP_1218-729 Store Secure Options to Forward Messages…
NTCIP_1218-731 Store Interval to Authenticate Messages …
NTCIP_1218-312

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to forward messages received from the V2X interface to a specified network destination. The configuration may be based on the type of message or the receive signal strength. This feature allows a manager to configure the network destination and the transport protocol. The receive signal strength is used to filter messages by signal strength.
NTCIP_1218-313
2.6.1.2.2.5 Manage Transmitted Messages over the V2X Interface for Forwarding
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-735 Determine Maximum Number of Message Entr…
NTCIP_1218-737 Store Network Destination to Forward Mes…
NTCIP_1218-739 Store Transport Protocol to Forward Mess…
NTCIP_1218-741 Store Start Time to Forward Messages Tra…
NTCIP_1218-743 Store Stop Time to Forward Messages Tran…
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
NTCIP_1218-314

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to forward messages transmitted over the V2X interface to a specified network destination. This feature allows a transportation manager to view what messages are being transmitted by the RSU over the V2X interface without looking at the interface logs on the RSU. The configuration may be based on the type of message. This feature allows a manager to configure the network destination and the transport protocol.
NTCIP_1218-315
2.6.1.2.3 Manage Logging of Interface Data
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-747 Determine Maximum Number of Interface Lo…
NTCIP_1218-749 Log Interface Data Identification
NTCIP_1218-755 Retrieve Interface Logged Data
NTCIP_1218-1133 Interface Data Log Format
NTCIP_1218-1135 Interface Data Log File Format
NTCIP_1218-1139 Support RSU Identifier in the Interface …
NTCIP_1218-1141 Support Interface Identifier in the Inte…
NTCIP_1218-1143 Support Direction in the Interface Data …
NTCIP_1218-1145 Support Date and Time in the Interface D…
NTCIP_1218-1150 Open a New Interface Data Log
NTCIP_1218-1152 Copy Files using SCP
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-751 Log Interface Data by Direction
NTCIP_1218-753 Store Interface Data Log - File Director…
NTCIP_1218-757 Store an Interface Data Log Start Time
NTCIP_1218-759 Store an Interface Data Log Stop Time
NTCIP_1218-761 Store Maximum Interface Data Log File Si…
NTCIP_1218-763 Store Maximum Interface Data Log File Co…
NTCIP_1218-765 Store Interface Data Log Option - Disk F…
NTCIP_1218-767 Store Interface Data Log Option - Entry …
NTCIP_1218-1147 Interface Data Logging - Operational Sta…
NTCIP_1218-316

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to log interface data. The interface log is used to log data packets across a network interface on the RSU for later analysis for the purposes of integration and diagnostics. This feature allows a manager to configure which network interface, the direction of data packets, the maximum log file size allowed, the maximum collection time, start time, end time, and collection interval to be logged. Each interface log entry includes the date and time the data packet was logged, the contents of the data packet and the RF signal levels for network interfaces using wireless communications. This feature is available for any RSU interface.
NTCIP_1218-317

2.6.1.3 Configure V2X Interface
NTCIP_1218-318

The features that allow a transportation manager to transmit and receive messages via a V2X interface follow.
NTCIP_1218-319
2.6.1.3.1 Enable/Disable Radios
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-781 Report Radio Operating Modes
NTCIP_1218-783 Report LTE-V2X Communications Status
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-773 Report Maximum Number of V2X Radios Supp…
NTCIP_1218-775 Report Type of V2X Radio
NTCIP_1218-777 Enable/Disable Radios
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-779 Report Radio MAC Address
NTCIP_1218-320

A transportation manager needs to enable and disable the radios controlled by the RSU. This feature allows the manager to enable and disable a radio when it is not used, either for security or to conserve energy.
NTCIP_1218-321
2.6.1.3.2 Determine Lower Layer Parameters
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-787 Determine Lower Layer Parameter
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-789 Determine Operating Class
NTCIP_1218-322

A transportation manager needs to retrieve the Lower Layer parameters for supporting wireless communications across the V2X interface. The Lower Layer parameters may include parameters such as transmit power, transmission rate and communications channel. This is a data dictionary standard - the lower layers deal with the implementation of the data dictionary standard.
NTCIP_1218-323
2.6.1.3.3 Configure IEEE 1609 Communications
NTCIP_1218-324

The features for transmitting and receiving messages using IEEE 1609 communications follow.
NTCIP_1218-325
2.6.1.3.3.1 Configure IEEE 1609.2 Security
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-795 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-797 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-799 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-801 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-803 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-805 Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-807 Report IEEE 1609.2 Application Certifica…
NTCIP_1218-809 Report IEEE 1609.2 Application Certifica…
NTCIP_1218-811 Store IEEE 1609.2 Application Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-815 Report Certificate Revocation List - Sou…
NTCIP_1218-817 Report Certificate Revocation List - Upd…
NTCIP_1218-819 Store Certificate Revocation List Update…
NTCIP_1218-821 Update Certificate Revocation List Comma…
NTCIP_1218-823 Report IEEE 1609.2 Security Profiles
NTCIP_1218-825 Configure Certificate Expiration Pending…
NTCIP_1218-1158 Determine Maximum Number of Application …
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-813 Store IEEE 1609.2 Application Certificat…
NTCIP_1218-326

A transportation manager needs to configure the IEEE 1609.2 security profiles used by the RSU. The IEEE 1609.2 defines security processing requirements and certificates for secure communications.
NTCIP_1218-327
2.6.1.3.3.2 Configure IEEE 1609.3 Communications - WSA
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-855 Report WSA Configuration – Extended Chan…
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-829 Determine Maximum Number of Services Adv…
NTCIP_1218-837 Store WSA Configuration – Secure [Deprec…
NTCIP_1218-840 Report WSA Version Number
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-831 Store WSA Configuration - Service Info S…
NTCIP_1218-833 Store WSA Configuration - Channel Info S…
NTCIP_1218-835 Configure WSA Configuration - WAVE Route…
NTCIP_1218-842 Store WSA Configuration – Secure V2
NTCIP_1218-845 Store WSA Configuration – WAVE Routing A…
NTCIP_1218-847 Store WSA Configuration – Repeat Rate
NTCIP_1218-849 Store WSA Configuration – 2D Location
NTCIP_1218-851 Store WSA Configuration – 3D Location
NTCIP_1218-853 Store WSA Configuration – RCPI Threshold
NTCIP_1218-328

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to advertise available services using an IEEE 1609.3 WAVE service advertisement (WSA). This feature allows a manager to configure the advertisement to support one or more applications. WSA are typically broadcast to connected devices to indicate channel assignments, PSID, priority, transmission rate, transmit power, and WAVE router advertisements (WRA).
NTCIP_1218-329
2.6.1.3.3.3 Configure IEEE 1609.4 Communications
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-1156 Time Fix - Alternating Mode
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-859 Store the IEEE 1609.4 Configuration for …
NTCIP_1218-862 Store Radio Channel Access Mode
NTCIP_1218-330

A transportation manager needs to configure the RSU use of IEEE 1609.4 multi-channel operations. This feature allows a manager to configure the radio to operate in one of the available multi-channel operations modes.
NTCIP_1218-331
2.6.1.3.3.4 Configure Radio Transmitter Properties
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-866 Store Default Transmit Power
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-869 Report Maximum Number of V2X Antennas Su…
NTCIP_1218-871 Store Antenna Gain and Cable Losses
NTCIP_1218-873 Store Antenna Type
NTCIP_1218-332

A transportation manager needs to configure the radio transmitter properties of the RSU. This feature stores information that is used for transmission power calculations.
NTCIP_1218-333

2.6.1.4 Manage RSU Applications
NTCIP_1218-334

The features that allow a transportation manager to manage the applications on an RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-335
2.6.1.4.1 Manage RSU Application
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-879 Install an RSU Application
NTCIP_1218-882 Report Software Update Status
NTCIP_1218-1152 Copy Files using SCP
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
NTCIP_1218-336

A transportation manager needs to manage the operational state of applications on the RSU. An RSU may have several software applications installed on the RSU to provide C-ITS services. This feature allows a manager to install, update or delete a software application residing on the RSU over the traffic management center to RSU interface. This feature also supports the transmission of the secure installation files, including executable application code and associated support files to support executing an application on the RSU. The application code may not be interoperable for all RSUs.
NTCIP_1218-337
2.6.1.4.2 Save and Restore Application Configuration
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-886 Install a Configuration File
NTCIP_1218-888 Report Configuration File Update Status
NTCIP_1218-1152 Copy Files using SCP
NTCIP_1218-338

A transportation manager needs to save and restore an application configuration on the RSU. The configuration defines the parameters for the RSU. In the event of a failed update the RSU reverts to the last configuration prior to the update. This feature allows a manager to restore a configuration in the event the integrity of the data on the RSU is affected or a parameter on the RSU is changed and impacts the operation of the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-339
2.6.1.4.3 Support Red Light Violation Warning Application
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-896 Receive SPaT Movement Status – NTCIP 120…
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-892 Receive Movement Maneuver Assist – NTCIP…
NTCIP_1218-894 Receive Advisory Speed – NTCIP 1202 v03B
NTCIP_1218-340

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to receive SPaT information from a traffic signal controller to support a Red Light Violation Warning (RLVW) application. This feature allows a manager to configure the RSU to process the SPaT information from the traffic signal controller and generate a J2735 SPaT message.
NTCIP_1218-341

The RLVW application on an OBU decreases the likelihood that the vehicle will be in the intersection during a red signal indication. When a vehicle is approaching an intersection during a green interval, the RLVW application may provide advisories, warnings, or alerts to the driver that they may not clear the intersection before the signal turns red.
NTCIP_1218-342

2.6.1.5 Manage Location Corrections
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-900 Forward Location Corrections Data
NTCIP_1218-902 Use RTCM Corrections Data
NTCIP_1218-343

A transportation manager needs to configure an RSU to compute and broadcast location correction data, such as RTCM, through the V2X interface. Location correction data can improve location accuracy. This feature allows a manager to identify the positioning corrections available and to configure the interval between broadcasts.
NTCIP_1218-344

2.6.2 Monitor the RSU
NTCIP_1218-345

The features that allow a transportation operator to monitor the processes and status of an RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-346

2.6.2.1 Determine RSU Operational Performance Status
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-908 Report Time Elapsed Since RSU Power On
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-910 Report Amount of Free Memory
NTCIP_1218-912 Report Instantaneous CPU Load
NTCIP_1218-914 Report CPU Load Average - 15 Minutes
NTCIP_1218-916 Report CPU Load Average - 5 Minutes
NTCIP_1218-918 Report CPU Load Average - 1 Minute
NTCIP_1218-920 Report Storage Space Available
NTCIP_1218-922 Report Number of Messages Exchanged
NTCIP_1218-347

A transportation operator needs to determine the operational performance of the RSU. This feature allows an operator to monitor the resources available on the RSU, such as the free memory available, the central processing unit (CPU) load (instantaneous, averaged over a period of time), the storage space available, the time elapsed since connectivity to the management center was restored, and the time elapsed since the RSU was operational or non-operational.
NTCIP_1218-348

2.6.2.2 Determine Mode of Operations
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-926 Report Mode of Operations
NTCIP_1218-349

A transportation operator needs to determine the current mode of operation of the RSU. This feature allows an operator to determine what functions and capabilities are currently enabled. The modes of operations are: fully operational, standby (non-transmit), and fault.
NTCIP_1218-350

2.6.2.3 Determine RSU Clock Status
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-943 Enable/Disable NTP Server
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-933 Report RSU Clock Source
NTCIP_1218-935 Report RSU Clock Status
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-937 Store Allowable RSU Clock Source Timeout
NTCIP_1218-939 Store Allowable RSU Clock Source Queries
NTCIP_1218-941 Store Allowable Time Deviation
NTCIP_1218-351

A transportation operator needs to check the validity of an RSU system clock. The system clock is used to assign timestamps on messages broadcasted by the RSU. The primary system clock for the RSU is expected to be based on a trusted GNSS source, but may have a secondary source, such as NTP. This feature allows an operator to view which clock source is currently active and to specify allowable tolerances for clock drifts. The system clock is also used to drive the scheduler.
NTCIP_1218-352

2.6.2.4 Determine RSU Location
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-947 Report RSU Location
NTCIP_1218-950 Report Positioning Status
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-952 Store Allowable RSU Location Tolerance
NTCIP_1218-954 Report RSU Location Deviation
NTCIP_1218-956 Report RSU Estimated Location Error
NTCIP_1218-353

A transportation operator needs to monitor the location information available to and used by an RSU. The location identifies the position of the RSU. Errors may include communication errors between the RSU and its location subsystem source or if there are sudden changes with the location data. Sudden changes to the location data may indicate an attack on the RSU, either physically or a cyberattack. If the location source is a GNSS device, this feature also allows the operator to monitor the number of GNSS satellites the GNSS receiver is tracking. For security purposes, the RSU may need to determine if it is within a legitimate boundary. This feature also transmits alerts if the RSU location changes or if errors are detected.
NTCIP_1218-354

2.6.2.5 Monitor Network Interfaces
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-960 Monitor Data Link Errors - Ethernet
NTCIP_1218-355

A transportation operator needs to monitor a network interface with the RSU. This feature allows an operator to retrieve network statistics and diagnostic information. The network interface includes the interface between the management station and the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-356

2.6.2.6 Report Number of Messages Exchanged
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-962 Report Number of Messages Exchanged by V…
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-922 Report Number of Messages Exchanged
NTCIP_1218-924 Determine Maximum Number of Monitored PS…
NTCIP_1218-357

A transportation operator needs to track the number of messages received and transmitted by the RSU for each interface. This can be used for diagnostics.
NTCIP_1218-358

2.6.2.7 Determine Number of Active Radios
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-964 Determine Number of Active Radios
NTCIP_1218-359

A transportation operator needs to monitor how many radios are active. This feature can be used to check the system status.
NTCIP_1218-360

2.6.2.8 Determine RF Communications Range
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-968 Determine Maximum Number of Communicatio…
NTCIP_1218-980 Report the Average RF Communications Dis…
NTCIP_1218-982 Manage RF Communications Range Statistic…
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-970 Report the RF Communications Distance - …
NTCIP_1218-972 Report the RF Communications Distance - …
NTCIP_1218-974 Report the RF Communications Distance - …
NTCIP_1218-976 Report the Average RF Communications Dis…
NTCIP_1218-978 Report the Average RF Communications Dis…
NTCIP_1218-361

A transportation operator needs to determine the communications range of the RSU. This feature allows an operator to determine the range of RF communications based on the position of the connected devices and how it might change with different weather conditions, interference conditions, foliage, construction, etc.
NTCIP_1218-362

2.6.2.9 Determine Application Status
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-984 Determine Application Status
NTCIP_1218-363

A transportation operator needs to monitor the status of the applications residing on the RSU. This feature allows an operator to determine what applications are currently running on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-364

2.6.2.10 Determine RSU Environment
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-625 Notification - Environmental
NTCIP_1218-988 Report the Internal Operating Temperatur…
NTCIP_1218-990 Determine the Internal Operating Tempera…
NTCIP_1218-365

A transportation operator needs to determine the operating environment of the RSU. This feature allows an operator to monitor for unsafe operating environments for the RSU so proper precautions can be taken. Unsafe operating environment includes excessive internal RSU temperatures.
NTCIP_1218-366

2.6.2.11 Determine RSU Current Status
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-1024 Report NTP Server Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1027 Report NTP Server Status
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-994 Report RSU Current Overall Status
NTCIP_1218-998 Report RSU System Services Status
NTCIP_1218-1000 Report GNSS Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1002 Report Time Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1004 Report Storage Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1006 Report Access Control Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1008 Report Network Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1010 Report Radio Access Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1012 Report V2X Radio Networking Services Sta…
NTCIP_1218-1014 Report IEEE 1609.2 Status
NTCIP_1218-1016 Report SCMS Service Status
NTCIP_1218-1018 Report Vendor Specific Services Status
NTCIP_1218-1020 Report RSU Services Description
NTCIP_1218-1022 Report RSU Services Status Update Time
NTCIP_1218-1160 Maximum notReady Time
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1029 Determine Maximum Number of Services Sup…
NTCIP_1218-367

A transportation operator needs to determine the current overall status of the RSU. This feature allows an operator to determine if any conditions exist on the RSU that requires additional monitoring, or if the RSU requires maintenance.
NTCIP_1218-368

2.6.3 Control the RSU
NTCIP_1218-369

The features that allow a transportation operator to control the operation of an RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-370

2.6.3.1 Control Mode of Operation
Conditionally met by:
NTCIP_1218-1046 Configure Diagnostic Mode Limit
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1033 Control Mode of Operation
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1043 Support Diagnostic Mode
NTCIP_1218-371

A transportation operator needs to control the mode of operation of an RSU. The mode of operation defines the ability for the RSU to process and exchange information with other devices. The modes of operations an operator can command an RSU to include fully operational, and standby (non-transmit) mode.
NTCIP_1218-372

2.6.3.2 Control RF Antenna Output
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1035 Control RF Antenna Output
NTCIP_1218-373

A transportation operator needs to configure the transmit output power for a radio of an RSU. This feature allows an operator to control the output power of a RF antenna, possibly to change the transmission area around the antenna in compliance with government (e.g., FCC) regulations. This is a default transmit output power for the RSU. An application residing on the RSU may elect to use a different output power for a message.
NTCIP_1218-374

2.6.3.3 Reboot RSU
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1037 Reboot RSU
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1041 Configure RSU Reboot
NTCIP_1218-375

A transportation operator needs to remotely reboot an RSU. This feature allows an operator to remotely (warm) reboot the RSU to attempt to recover from a software failure or other operational failures. This feature is desired to avoid a field trip to reboot the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-376

2.6.3.4 Control Application
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1039 Control Application
NTCIP_1218-377

A transportation operator needs to remotely manage an application on the RSU. An RSU may have several applications installed on the RSU to provide C-ITS services. This feature allows an operator to enable/disable or restart an application residing on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-378

2.6.4 Receive Information from ITS Roadside Device
NTCIP_1218-379

The features that allow a RSU to receive data from an ITS Roadside Device follow.
NTCIP_1218-380

2.6.4.1 Receive SPaT Information
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-896 Receive SPaT Movement Status – NTCIP 120…
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-892 Receive Movement Maneuver Assist – NTCIP…
NTCIP_1218-894 Receive Advisory Speed – NTCIP 1202 v03B
NTCIP_1218-381

A RSU needs to receive near real-time SPaT information from a traffic signal controller so the RSU may either generate an SAE J2735 SPaT message or to forward an SAE J2735 SPaT message over the V2X Interface.
