The ability for an RSU to transmit SPaT messages is an important capability to improve surface transportation safety at signalized intersections.
NTCIP_1218-382

2.6.5 Backward Compatibility Features
NTCIP_1218-383

The following sub-features were modified within NTCIP 1218 v01A and needed to be specifically spelled out to achieve backward compatibility for certain features within an RSU conforming to NTCIP 1218 v01.
NTCIP_1218-384

2.6.5.1 Backward Compatible with NTCIP 1218 v01
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1069 NTCIP 1218 v01 – Store a Message
NTCIP_1218-1071 NTCIP 1218 v01 - Store WSA Configuration…
NTCIP_1218-1073 NTCIP 1218 v01 - Support SHA-1
NTCIP_1218-1078 NTCIP 1218 v01 - Support DTLS
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1076 NTCIP 1218 v01 - Support SHA-2
NTCIP_1218-385

A newer transportation system component needs to communicate with other components that conform to NTCIP 1218 v01.
NTCIP_1218-386

2.7 Security
2024-08-07: Kenneth Vaughn

Do we need to specify a "consistent" level of support for NTCIP 1218 as we are doing for SNMPv1 MIB standards? One could argue that this would allow devices that are not conformant with ISO 15784-2 for a while, but I don't know that there is a pressing need for this category of devices and defining it could create confusion (i.e., 1218 would have a unique meaning for consistent)
NTCIP_1218-2109

This document standardizes the objects that can be used by a remote entity to monitor and/or control a device. Allowing remote operations without providing sufficient information security can have a negative effect on the communications network and/or the transportation system. In particular, the mis-configuration of "read-write" and/or "read-create" objects can result in the activation of unauthorized features or unauthorized changes to the device configuration; these changes can result in potentially hazardous situations.
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

Added boilerplate
NTCIP_1218-2110

Further, even failing to secure exchanges of "read-only" objects can have harmful effects. Providing unauthorized access to read-only objects can reveal information about the device that can be useful in conducting a cyber-attack against the device itself, other devices, and potentially the central system. Likewise, failing to authenticate the source of the read-only data allows a cyber threat actor to potentially impersonate the device and provide false information to a traffic management center.
NTCIP_1218-2111

The object types defined by this document are intended to be transmitted over SNMPv3. SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 do not include adequate security. Prior SNMP versions do not provide any control as to who on the network is allowed to access and read/change/create/delete objects, even if the network itself is secure.
NTCIP_1218-387

The security features that may be offered by the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-388

2.7.1 Manage Authentication
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-603 Notification - Signature Verification Er…
NTCIP_1218-615 Notification - Certificate Management
NTCIP_1218-1154 User Accounts
Optionally fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1054 Report Valid Geographic Region - Enrollm…
NTCIP_1218-1057 Report Valid Geographic Region - Enrollm…
NTCIP_1218-389

A transportation manager needs to manage the RSU to authenticate the management station that the RSU is exchanging data (transmitting to or receiving from). This feature allows a transportation manager to configure whether the management station that is monitoring or configuring the RSU is “trusted” and, therefore, unlikely to provide data that can adversely affect the cooperative-ITS system.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

The traceability from this UN does not really align with the text. i.e., reporting an authentication error on another interface is not authentication for this interface. Authentication for this interface is covered separately in ISO 15784-2, 7.8.6 (i.e., support for (D)TLS), and the SNMPv2-MIB for reporting issues (i.e., RFC 3418)

Proposal: Create separate use need for 1) reporting the identified notifications and 2) reporting the valid coverage areas when requested.
NTCIP_1218-390

2.7.2 Manage Data Integrity
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

The traces do not align with the user need. We should change the user need to identify the need to receive notification of integrity failures.
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-597 Notification - Integrity Check Error - A…
NTCIP_1218-599 Notification - Integrity Check Error - S…
NTCIP_1218-1097 Access RSU - USM
NTCIP_1218-391

A transportation manager needs to configure the RSU to protect the integrity of the data exchanged and stored on it and to verify that the content of data is unchanged when received or stored. For data exchanges, that the data contents when transmitted are the same as when received; and are not corrupted and used for misbehavior.
NTCIP_1218-392

2.7.3 Manage Availability
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

The traces do not align with the user need. We should change the user need to identify the need to receive notification of availability failures.
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-605 Notification - Network Access Control Li…
NTCIP_1218-1061 Report Expiration Date - Enrollment Cert…
NTCIP_1218-1063 Report Expiration Date - Application Cer…
NTCIP_1218-393

A transportation manager needs to configure the RSU so that the RSU and its data are available to authorized users and processes. This feature allows a transportation manager to configure the RSU to permit appropriate processes and users timely and reliable access to the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-394

2.7.4 Manage Confidentiality
2024-08-07: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete: covered by ISO 15784-2. Replace with following requirement (revised from other standards)
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-1097 Access RSU - USM
NTCIP_1218-1099 Access RSU - TSM
NTCIP_1218-1101 Support AES-256 Encryption
NTCIP_1218-395

A transportation manager needs to configure the RSU to protect the data exchanged with the RSU from unauthorized viewing. This feature protects the data from being used by hostile parties to attack the cooperative-ITS infrastructure.
NTCIP_1218-2112

2.7.5 Provide secure environment

Users need the device to support a secure communications environment without any unsecured protocol.
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

Added user need for standard security
Fulfilled by:
NTCIP_1218-2113 Security requirements
NTCIP_1218-2114

This excludes support for less secure protocols, such as SNMP versions prior to SNMP3. In other words, conformant devices do not have the installed code to activate prior versions of SNMP.
NTCIP_1218-396

2.8 Operational Policies and Constraints
NTCIP_1218-397

NTCIP 1218 assumes that the following constraints apply.
NTCIP_1218-1438

Agencies have operational policies in place that limit physical access to authorized personnel and remote access to authorized personnel. It is recommended that the operational policies require each manager and operator be individually identified when accessing the RSU, and thus, each manager and operator should have their own username.
NTCIP_1218-1439

It is the operational policy of some agencies that authorized personnel is/are present at the physical location of the RSU, before an RSU accepts a change to the configuration of the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-1440

Protocols defining communications to the RSU are limited to protocols already defined in another standard or RFC.
NTCIP_1218-1441

Agencies may also have policies and practices that limit the hours of operation of transportation managers and operators. RSU may need to be scheduled for operation.
NTCIP_1218-1442

NTCIP 1218 defines a MIB and requires a compatible communications protocol.
NTCIP_1218-1443

Connected Transportation Interoperability (CTI) 4001, Roadside Unit (RSU) Standard, defines a non-proprietary, communications-agnostic, industry consensus RSU Standard, which references NTCIP 1218 for its communications interface.
NTCIP_1218-398

2.9 Relationship to the ITS National Architecture [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-399

Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation, known as ARC-IT, combines the National ITS Architecture and the Connected Vehicle Reference Implementation Architecture (CVRIA). Figure 4 represents the physical view of the RSU system as depicted in ARC-IT - each color box represents an ITS class defined in ARC-IT. Figure 4 is similar to Figure 1 with the addition of Support Services, which represents the security and directory services in this diagram.
NTCIP_1218-400
NTCIP_1218-400_1_image004.png
NTCIP_1218-402

ARC-IT identifies a set of information flows that interface between an RSU, represented in ARC-IT as Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment (CVRE), and other entities, including a center (CEN), Field Maintenance Equipment (FME), and Service Monitor System (SMS). As a subset of these flows, only flows not specific to individual ITS applications are addressed by NTCIP 1218 as they represent the configuration, monitoring, and control of Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment. These information flows are the following:
NTCIP_1218-403

The main user need groups (features), as identified in Section 2.5, are related to the information flows as shown in Table 1. There are more than 300 ARC-IT triples that include Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment, which represents an RSU. Each information flow triple represents a source and destination Physical Object and the information flow that is exchanged. Of these, ten (10) triples are addressed by NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-1444

Device Identification.An identifier and device type designation that is used to uniquely identify a device in the Connected Vehicle Environment.
NTCIP_1218-1445

Equipment Control Commands.System-level control commands issued to the RSE such as reset and remote diagnostics.
NTCIP_1218-1446

RSE Application Information.RSE application configuration data and parameters that are used to control applications and configure the application for a specific local use. This flow also supports remote control of the application so the application can be taken offline, reset, or restarted.
NTCIP_1218-1447

RSE Application Install/Upgrade.This flow supports remote installation and update of software applications residing in the RSE. It supports transmission of the secure software installation files, including executable application code and associated support files.
NTCIP_1218-1448

RSE Application Status.Monitoring of RSE application status including current mode, operational status, and configuration settings. It includes the status of installed applications and the application-specific data provided by the RSE.
NTCIP_1218-1449

RSE Configuration Settings.Control settings and parameters that are used to configure roadside equipment.
NTCIP_1218-1450

RSE Status.Monitoring of RSE device status including current mode, operational status, and configuration settings. It includes device housekeeping/heartbeat monitoring and includes network information, the status of installed applications, the configuration of managed devices, cybersecurity and physical security status of the RSE.
NTCIP_1218-404

User Need Group

Source

Information Flow

Destination

Manage the RSU Configuration

CEN

RSE Application Information

CVRE

Manage the RSU Configuration

CEN

RSE Application Install/Upgrade

CVRE

Manage the RSU Configuration

FME

RSE Application Install/Upgrade

CVRE

Manage the RSU Configuration

FME

RSE Configuration Settings

CVRE

Monitor the RSU

CVRE

Device Identification

CEN

Monitor the RSU

CVRE

RSE Application Status

CEN

Monitor the RSU

CVRE

RSE Status

FME

Monitor the RSU

CVRE

RSE Status

SMS

Control the RSU

CEN

Equipment Control Commands

CVRE

Control the RSU

FME

Equipment Control Commands

CVRE
NTCIP_1218-405

Where:
     CEN = Center
     CVRE = Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment
     FME = Field Maintenance Equipment
     SMS = Service Monitor System
NTCIP_1218-410

3 Functional Requirements [Normative]
NTCIP_1218-411

Section 3 defines the Functional Requirements based on the user needs identified in the Concept of Operations (see Section 2). Section 3 includes the following:
NTCIP_1218-1454

A tutorial.
NTCIP_1218-1455

Protocol Requirements List (PRL) – A Functional Requirement is a requirement of a given function and therefore is only required to be implemented if the associated functionality (e.g., user need) is selected through the use of the PRL. The PRL also indicates which of the items are mandatory, conditional, or optional. The PRL can be used by procurement personnel to specify the desired features of an RSU system or can be used by a manufacturer to document the features supported by their implementation.
NTCIP_1218-1456

Architectural Requirements – These are requirements related to the architectural needs defined in Section 2.4.
NTCIP_1218-1457

Data Exchange and Operational Environment Requirements – These are requirements related to the features identified in Sections 2.5 and 2.6 that can be realized through a data exchange. For example, this includes the requirement to be able to monitor what signal indications are active.
NTCIP_1218-1458

Supplemental Non-communications Requirements – These are additional requirements derived from the Concept of Operations that do not fall into one of the above two categories. For example, they include requirements related to performance requirements.
NTCIP_1218-412

Section 3 is intended for all readers, including the following:
NTCIP_1218-1459

Transportation Managers
NTCIP_1218-1460

Transportation Operators
NTCIP_1218-1461

Transportation Engineers
NTCIP_1218-1462

Maintenance Personnel
NTCIP_1218-1463

System Integrators
NTCIP_1218-1464

Device Manufacturers
NTCIP_1218-413

For the first four categories of readers, Section 3 is useful in understanding the details that NTCIP 1218 requires of an RSU. For these readers, Section 3.3.3 is particularly useful in preparing procurement specifications and assists in mapping the various rows of this table to the more detailed text contained within the other sections.
NTCIP_1218-414

For the last two categories of readers, this section is useful to fully understand what is required of equipment meeting this interface standard. Table 6 in Section 3.3.3 may be used to document the capabilities of their implementations.
NTCIP_1218-415

3.1 Tutorial [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-416

This Functional Requirements section defines the formal requirements that are intended to satisfy the user needs identified in Section 2. This is achieved through the development of a PRL that traces each user need to one or more requirements defined in this section. The details of each requirement are then presented following the PRL. The functional requirements are presented in three broad categories as follows:
NTCIP_1218-1451

Architectural Requirements – These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface, including any restrictions to general architectural requirements, based upon the architectural needs identified in the Concept of Operations.
NTCIP_1218-1452

Data Exchange Requirements – These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface based upon the features identified in the Concept of Operations.
NTCIP_1218-1453

Supplemental Requirements – These requirements define additional requirements of the system that are derived from the architectural and/or data exchange requirements but are not themselves architectural or data exchange requirements. A given supplemental requirement may relate to multiple architectural and/or data exchange requirements. Supplemental requirements include capabilities of the equipment (e.g., service processing or clearing expired priority requests) and security functions.
NTCIP_1218-417

3.2 Scope of The Interface [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-418

NTCIP 1218 specifies the logical interface between an RSU and a controlling management station, such as a central management system. NTCIP 1218 defines information that may be exchanged across this interface to allow a management station to configure, monitor, and control the RSU, as described by the features in Sections 2.5 and 2.6.
NTCIP_1218-419

NTCIP 1218 is only one component for defining the complete functions and capabilities of a deployed RSU. NTCIP 1218 does not, for example, address the communications interface between the RSU and the connected devices, such as an OBU; nor the communications interface between the RSU and other ITS Roadside Devices. Those communications interfaces are addressed by other standards, such as IEEE 802.11, IEEE 1609.x, SAE J2735, and SAE J2945/x for the interface between the RSU and connected devices. However, NTCIP 1218 does address the configuration of the RSU to enable communications across that interface.
NTCIP_1218-420

NTCIP 1218 also only addresses a small portion of the security system for an RSU and the overall connected vehicle environment. Security is a crucial consideration in the deployment of the connected vehicle environment. A security system in the connected vehicle environment allows the exchange of trusted data in a safe, secure manner without compromising privacy. NTCIP 1218 only addresses security for the RSU as related to those functions that can be configured by a Management Information Base (MIB) and functions related to machine-to-machine connections (i.e., NTCIP 1218 does not address human-to-machine connections).
NTCIP_1218-421

NTCIP 1218 does support uploading an application to an RSU and to determine if an application is running on the RSU. However, NTCIP 1218 does not address the configuration of the application, or the specifications for application that may reside on an RSU (i.e., it does not address what applications should be on an RSU).
NTCIP_1218-422

As a communications interface, NTCIP 1218 also does not address hardware, mechanical or electrical requirements for an RSU, nor does it address the communications performance of the wireless radio.
NTCIP_1218-423

3.3 Protocol Requirements List (PRL)
NTCIP_1218-424

The PRL, provided in Table 6 defined in Section 3.3.3, maps the user needs defined in Section 2 to the requirements defined in Section 3. The PRL can be used by the following individuals:
NTCIP_1218-1465

A user or specification writer to indicate which requirements are to be implemented in a project-specific implementation.
NTCIP_1218-1466

The protocol implementer, as a checklist to reduce the risk of failure to conform to the standard through oversight.
NTCIP_1218-1467

The device manufacturer and user, as a detailed indication of the capabilities of the implementation.
NTCIP_1218-1468

The user, as a basis for initially checking the potential interoperability with another implementation.
NTCIP_1218-1469

The tester, as a checklist to compare against a specification and provide basis for test planning.
NTCIP_1218-425

3.3.1 Notation [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-426

The following notations and symbols are used to indicate status and conditional status in the PRL within all NTCIP standards. Not all of these notations and symbols may be used within NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-427

3.3.1.1 Conformance Symbols
NTCIP_1218-428

The symbols in Table 2 are used to indicate status under the Conformance column in the PRL.
NTCIP_1218-430
3.3.1.1.1 Symbol

Status
NTCIP_1218-431
3.3.1.1.2 M

Mandatory
NTCIP_1218-432
3.3.1.1.3 M.#

Support of every item of the group labeled by the same numeral # is required, but only one is active at a time
NTCIP_1218-433
3.3.1.1.4 O

Optional
NTCIP_1218-434
3.3.1.1.5 O.# (range)

Part of an option group. Support of the number of items indicated by the ‘(range)’ is required from all options labeled with the same numeral #
NTCIP_1218-435
3.3.1.1.6 C

Conditional
NTCIP_1218-436
3.3.1.1.7 NA

Not-applicable (i.e. logically impossible in the scope of the standard)
NTCIP_1218-437
3.3.1.1.8 X

Excluded or prohibited
NTCIP_1218-438

The O.# (range) notation is used to show a set of selectable options (e.g., O.2 (1..*) would indicate that one or more of the option group 2 options shall be implemented). Two-character combinations are used for dynamic requirements. In this case, the first character refers to the static (implementation) status, and the second refers to the dynamic (use); thus, "MO" means "mandatory to be implemented, optional to be used."
NTCIP_1218-439

3.3.1.2 Conditional Status Notation
NTCIP_1218-440

The predicate notations in Table 3 may be used.
NTCIP_1218-442
3.3.1.2.1 Predicate

Notation
NTCIP_1218-443
3.3.1.2.2 <predicate>:

This notation introduces a single item that is conditional on the <predicate>.
NTCIP_1218-444
3.3.1.2.3 <predicate>::

This notation introduces a table or a group of tables, all of which are conditional on the <predicate>.
NTCIP_1218-445
3.3.1.2.4 (predicate)

This notation introduces the first occurrence of the predicate. The feature associated with this notation is the base feature for all options that have this predicate in their conformance column.
NTCIP_1218-446

The <predicate>: notation means that the status following it applies only when the PRL states that the feature or features identified by the predicate are supported. In the simplest case, <predicate> is the identifying tag of a single PRL item. The <predicate> notation may precede a table or group of tables in a section or subsection. When the group predicate is true then the associated section shall be completed. The symbol <predicate> also may be a Boolean expression composed of several indices. "AND," "OR," and "NOT" shall be used to indicate the Boolean logical operations.
NTCIP_1218-447

The predicates used in NTCIP 1218 v01 map to the sections indicated in Table 4.
NTCIP_1218-449
3.3.1.2.5 Predicate

Section
NTCIP_1218-450
3.3.1.2.6 Alternating

3.5.1.3.3.3.2 (If Alternating is selected)
NTCIP_1218-451
3.3.1.2.7 Diagnostic

3.5.3.6
NTCIP_1218-452
3.3.1.2.8 DSRC

2.3.2.a
NTCIP_1218-453
3.3.1.2.9 GNSSOut

3.5.1.1.3.6.1
NTCIP_1218-454
3.3.1.2.10 Inform

3.5.1.1.7.4
NTCIP_1218-455
3.3.1.2.11 LongLoss

3.5.1.1.6.2
NTCIP_1218-456
3.3.1.2.12 NTP

3.5.2.3.6
NTCIP_1218-457
3.3.1.2.13 PC5

2.3.2.b
NTCIP_1218-458
3.3.1.2.14 ShortLoss

3.5.1.1.6.1
NTCIP_1218-459
3.3.1.2.15 StartupFault

3.5.1.1.4.4
NTCIP_1218-460
3.3.1.2.16 Temp

3.5.2.10.1
NTCIP_1218-461

3.3.1.3 Support Column Symbols
NTCIP_1218-462

The Support column in the PRL can be used by a procurement specification to identify the required features for the given procurement or by an implementer to identify which features have been implemented. In either case, the user circles the appropriate answer (Yes, No, or N/A) in the support column:
NTCIP_1218-464
3.3.1.3.1 Entry

Identifier
NTCIP_1218-465
3.3.1.3.2 Yes

Supported by the implementation
NTCIP_1218-466
3.3.1.3.3 No

Not supported by the implementation
NTCIP_1218-467
3.3.1.3.4 N/A

Not applicable
NTCIP_1218-468

3.3.2 Instructions for Completing the PRL [Informative]
NTCIP_1218-469

In the ‘Support’ column, each response shall be selected either from the indicated set of responses (for example: Yes / No / NA), or it shall reference additional items that are to be attached (for example, list of traffic signal controllers to be supported by an implementation).
NTCIP_1218-470

If a conditional requirement is inapplicable, use the Not Applicable (NA) choice. If a mandatory requirement is not satisfied, exception information shall be supplied by entering a reference Xi, where “i” is a unique identifier, to an accompanying rationale for the non-conformance. When the status is expressed as a two-character combination (as defined in 3.3.1.1 above), the response shall address each element of the requirement; e.g., for the requirement "mo," the possible compliant responses are "yy" or "yn."
NTCIP_1218-471

Note: A specification can allow for flexibility in a deliverable by leaving the selection in the Support column blank for a given row.
NTCIP_1218-472

3.3.2.1 Conformance Definition
NTCIP_1218-473

To claim "Conformance" to NTCIP 1218 v01A, the manufacturer shall minimally fulfill the mandatory requirements as identified in the PRL table (see Table 6).
NTCIP_1218-474

Note: The reader and user of NTCIP 1218 v01A is advised that 'conformance' to NTCIP 1218 v01A should not be confused with 'compliance' to a specification. NTCIP 1218 v01A is as broad as possible to allow a very simple RSU implementation to be 'conformant' to NTCIP 1218 v01A. An agency specification needs to identify the requirements of a particular project and needs to require the support of those requirements. A specification writer is advised to match the requirements of a project with the corresponding standardized requirements defined in NTCIP 1218 v01A to achieve interoperability. This means that functions and requirements defined as 'optional' in NTCIP 1218 v01A might need to be selected in a specification (in effect made 'mandatory' for the project-specific specification).
NTCIP_1218-475

A conformant device may offer additional (optional) features, as long as they are conformant with the requirements of NTCIP 1218 v01A and the standards it references (e.g., NTCIP 1201 v03). For example, to claim conformance to additional features, an implementation shall conform to all of the mandatory and selected optional requirements that trace to the subject user needs in the PRL, AND shall fulfill the requirement by using all of the dialogs and data elements traced to the subject requirement in the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) in Annex A.
NTCIP_1218-476

A device may also support data that has not been defined by NTCIP 1218 v01A; however, when exchanged via an SNMP-like protocol, the data shall be properly registered with a valid OBJECT IDENTIFIER under the Global ISO Naming Tree.
NTCIP_1218-477

Note: Off-the-shelf interoperability and interchangeability can only be obtained through well documented features broadly supported by the industry as a whole. Designing a system that uses features not defined in a standard or not typically deployed in combination with one another inhibits the goals of interoperability and interchangeability, especially if the documentation of these features is not available for distribution to system integrators. Standards allow the use of additional features to support innovation, which is constantly needed within the industry; but users should be aware of the risks involved with using such features.
NTCIP_1218-478

To claim "Conformance" to NTCIP 1218 v01A, an RSU device shall be provided with a MIB that contains all non-NTCIP-standardized (including custom, proprietary and manufacturer-, agency-, or implementation-specific) object and block definitions. Object and block definitions contained in the MIB shall:
NTCIP_1218-1470

Use the ASN.1 notation and conventions used in NTCIP 1218 v01A standardized object and block definitions.
NTCIP_1218-1471

Include non-NTCIP-standardized enumerations.
NTCIP_1218-1472

Include meaningful, human-understandable, English language DESCRIPTION fields including descriptions of the object and all supported values.
NTCIP_1218-479

In addition, to claim "Conformance" to NTCIP 1218 v01A, an RSU device shall use the NTCIP 1218 v01A standardized objects to manage NTCIP 1218 v01A functionality. Non-NTCIP-standardized objects may be used to manage NTCIP 1218 v01 functionality only if NTCIP 1218 v01A standardized objects for the same functions are also supported. RSU devices or systems attempting to manage, configure, or monitor an NTCIP 1218 v01A standardized object shall not be required to use proprietary objects for NTCIP 1218 v01A functionality.
NTCIP_1218-480

3.3.3 Protocol Requirements List (PRL) Table
NTCIP_1218-481

In addition to the Conformance column and the Support column, which were discussed in Sections 3.3.1 and 3.3.2, the additional columns in the PRL table are the User Need ID and User Need columns, FR ID and Functional Requirements columns and the Additional Specifications column.
NTCIP_1218-482

User Need ID - the number assigned to the user need statement. The user needs are defined within Section 2 and the PRL is based upon the user need sections within that Section.
NTCIP_1218-483

User Need – a short descriptive title identifying the user need.
NTCIP_1218-484

FR ID – the number assigned to the functional requirement statement. The requirements are defined within Section 3 and the PRL references the traces from user needs to these requirements.
NTCIP_1218-485

Functional Requirement – a short descriptive title identifying the functional requirement.
NTCIP_1218-486

Additional Specifications - identifies other requirements to satisfy, including user selectable range values. The "Additional Specifications" column may (and should) be used by a procurement specification to provide additional notes and requirements for the product to be procured or may be used by an implementer to provide any additional details about the implementation. In some cases, default text already exists in this field, which the user should complete to fully specify the equipment. However, additional text can be added to this field as needed to fully specify a feature.
NTCIP_1218-487

Note: Visit www.ntcip.org for information on availability of electronic copies of the PRL.
NTCIP_1218-488

<See Links Column>
NTCIP_1218-489

3.4 Common Requirements

Requirements for common NTCIP capabilities are provided in ISO 26048-1. 
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Renamed from Architectural Requirements to common requirements and replace text with reference to ISO 26048-1
NTCIP_1218-490

This subsection is primarily present so that all other requirements can maintain numbering consistency with prior versions.
NTCIP_1218-491

3.4.1 Support Basic Communications Requirements
NTCIP_1218-492

Requirements for a transportation manager and transportation operator to make requests to an RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-493

3.4.1.1 Retrieve Data
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-274 Configure, Monitor, and Control the RSU
NTCIP_1218-494

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall provide the data requested. This is a high-level requirement. The exact detailed requirements for the RSU to provide the specific values of data requested are defined by numerous functional requirements found in Section 3.5, Data Exchange and Operational Environment Requirements.
NTCIP_1218-495

3.4.1.2 Deliver Data
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-274 Configure, Monitor, and Control the RSU
NTCIP_1218-496

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall receive the data (e.g., configuration data, commands, etc.) provided. This is a high-level requirement. The exact detailed requirements to store the specific values of data requested are defined by numerous functional requirements found in Section 3.5, Data Exchange and Operational Environment Requirements.
NTCIP_1218-497

3.4.1.3 Explore Data
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-274 Configure, Monitor, and Control the RSU
NTCIP_1218-498

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall allow dynamic discovery of the data concepts and data instances supported by the RSU. This requirement allows a management station to "walk" a MIB. This is a high-level requirement. The exact detailed requirements to report the data and data values supported are defined by numerous functional requirements found in Section 3.5, Data Exchange and Operational Environment Requirements.
NTCIP_1218-499

3.4.2 Log Data Local Storage and Retrieval Requirements
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Replaced with fdSysLog
NTCIP_1218-500

Requirements for a transportation manager and transportation operator to configure and retrieve logged data from the RSU follow. The logged data contain information about the RSU and events that occur on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-501

3.4.2.1 Configure Priority Level for Events
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1833 System Log Severity
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-276 Provide for Log Data Local Storage and R…
NTCIP_1218-502

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the priority level of events that can be recorded for the event logging service. The valid priority levels are defined in Table 2 in RFC 5424. This requirement allows a manager to define the priority level of events recorded by the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-503

3.4.2.2 Close an Active Event Log File
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1832 System Log Close Command
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-276 Provide for Log Data Local Storage and R…
NTCIP_1218-504

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall command the open (active) event log file that the RSU is currently storing logged events to close, at the earliest convenient time.
NTCIP_1218-505

Note: Some event log implementations automatically close open event log files, and thus may not support this requirement.
NTCIP_1218-506

3.4.2.3 Retrieve Event Logged Data
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1212 Retrieve Event Logged Data Dialog
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1827 System Log Query Start Time
NTCIP_1218-1828 System Log Query Stop Time
NTCIP_1218-1829 System Log Query Priority
NTCIP_1218-1830 System Log Query Generate
NTCIP_1218-1831 System Log Query Status
NTCIP_1218-1839 System Log Name
NTCIP_1218-1840 System Base Directory
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-276 Provide for Log Data Local Storage and R…
NTCIP_1218-507

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall return the logged data from its event log. This requirement allows the management station to filter the logged data based on start and end times and by priority level.
NTCIP_1218-508

3.4.3 Condition-based Exception Reporting
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Supersede with fdNotifications
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-278 Condition-based Exception Reporting
NTCIP_1218-509

Upon detection of specified events, the RSU shall transmit a notification to a specified management station of the event occurrence. This is a high-level requirement. The exact detailed requirements to report the data and data values supported are defined by numerous functional requirements found in Section 3.5.1.1.7, Manage Notification Requirements.
NTCIP_1218-510

3.5 Data Exchange and Operational Environment Requirements
NTCIP_1218-511

Data exchange requirements for the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-512

3.5.1 RSU Configuration Management Requirements
NTCIP_1218-513

The requirements for managing the RSU configuration follow.
NTCIP_1218-514

3.5.1.1 RSU Device Management Requirements
NTCIP_1218-515

The requirements for managing the RSU device follow.
NTCIP_1218-516
3.5.1.1.1 Retrieve RSU Identity Requirements
NTCIP_1218-517

The requirements to identify the RSU follows.
NTCIP_1218-518
3.5.1.1.1.1 Store RSU Identifier
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

How is this different than sysName?
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1812 RSU Identifier
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-285 Retrieve RSU Identity
NTCIP_1218-519

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store its assigned identifier. The identifier is a text string from 0 to 32 characters in length.
NTCIP_1218-520
3.5.1.1.1.2 Report RSU Component Information
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete (replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.8.2.1.4, 8.8.2.1.6)
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1179 Generic Retrieve Table Dialog - Static T…
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-285 Retrieve RSU Identity
NTCIP_1218-521

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the identification information for each module contained in the RSU. The identification information consists of:
NTCIP_1218-1473

The manufacturer of the module.
NTCIP_1218-1474

The model number or firmware reference of the module.
NTCIP_1218-1475

The version of the module.
NTCIP_1218-1476

An indication of whether it is a software or hardware module.
NTCIP_1218-522
3.5.1.1.1.3 Report Supported Standards
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete (replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.7)
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-285 Retrieve RSU Identity
NTCIP_1218-523

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the communications standards (and versions) supported by the RSU, with each communication standard indicator separated by a comma. The description consists of a text field up to 255 characters in length.
NTCIP_1218-524
3.5.1.1.1.4 Report RSU System Name
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete (replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.1)
Satisfied by:
rfc3418-7 sysName
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-285 Retrieve RSU Identity
NTCIP_1218-525

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the unique system name of the RSU. This system name could be any unique value such as a serial number up to 255 characters in length.
NTCIP_1218-526
3.5.1.1.1.5 Report RSU MIB Version
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete (replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.7)
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1809 RSU MIB Version
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-285 Retrieve RSU Identity
NTCIP_1218-527

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the identity and version of the MIB(s) in use. The module identity allows the manager to identify what version of a standard, as well as the standards and specifications it references; and what version of private objects are supported and referenced. The module identity is assigned by the manufacturer.
NTCIP_1218-528
3.5.1.1.2 Report Deployment Configuration Identifier
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete (replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.5.2.14)
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-287 Retrieve Configuration Version of the RS…
NTCIP_1218-529

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the unique identifier created using a checksum-creation-like algorithm across all configuration parameters contained in the RSU database. The RSU creates the identifier at powerup and is updated whenever changes are made to any of the RSU configuration parameters.
NTCIP_1218-530

The management station may use this unique identifier to determine if the current configuration of the RSU is as expected. If the reported unique identifier is different, then the configuration of the RSU may have changed, possibly as a result of a change initiated by another management station, such as a maintenance worker in the field.
NTCIP_1218-531

Note: For NTCIP 1218, how the unique identifier is generated is allowed to be vendor-specific. This allows the vendor to include other parameters, which may be stored in vendor-specific (private) object identifiers or not stored in an object identifier, as part of the algorithm to generate the unique identifier. Any changes to a configuration (static) parameter should result in a change in the unique identifier.
NTCIP_1218-532
3.5.1.1.3 Manage RSU Location Requirements
NTCIP_1218-533

The requirements for managing the physical location of the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-534
3.5.1.1.3.1 Store RSU Location Description
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1811 RSU Location Description
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-535

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a textual description of its location. The description consists of a text field up to 140 characters in length.
NTCIP_1218-536
3.5.1.1.3.2 Store RSU Location
2024-11-12: Kenneth Vaughn

Should this be replaced with the ISO 26048-1 location objects?
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1813 RSU Reference Location - Latitude
NTCIP_1218-1814 RSU Reference Location - Longitude
NTCIP_1218-1815 RSU Reference Location - Elevation
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-537

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store its reference location, as provided within the request. The RSU location consists of the latitude, longitude, and elevation. The latitude and longitude are in tenths of a microdegree (10^-7 degrees) using the WGS-84 (World Geodetic System 1984). The elevation of the RSU is in centimeters above the reference ellipsoid as defined by the WGS-84, and is measured to the base of the GNSS antenna.
NTCIP_1218-538

Note: FR 3.5.2.4.1 provides the location of the RSU as reported by a GNSS or similar geopositioning device.
NTCIP_1218-539
3.5.1.1.3.3 Store RSU Location - GNSS Antenna Offset
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1816 RSU Reference Location - Elevation Offse…
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-540

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the offset in elevation, in centimeters, between the antenna used by a GNSS or similar geopositioning device and the base of the structure that the RSU is mounted on. An RSU determines its geographic location based on data from a GNSS or similar geopositioning device. The geographic position provided by a GNSS (or similar) device is usually based on the location of antenna - the longitude and latitude of the antenna is generally the same location of the RSU, but the height of the antenna is normally higher than the base of the structure. This requirement allows the GNSS data to be adjusted for the height differential.

NOTE — This requirement assumes that there is only one GNSS antenna.
NTCIP_1218-541
3.5.1.1.3.4 Store V2X Antenna Offsets
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1195 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1852 Antenna Table
NTCIP_1218-1855 RSU Antenna Index
NTCIP_1218-1856 RSU V2X Antenna - Latitude
NTCIP_1218-1857 RSU V2X Antenna - Longitude
NTCIP_1218-1858 RSU V2X Antenna - Elevation
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-542

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the location (latitude, longitude, and elevation) of the base of each V2X antenna. The latitude and longitude are in tenths of a microdegree (10^-7 degrees) using the WGS-84 (World Geodetic System 1984). The elevation is in centimeters above the reference ellipsoid as defined by the WGS-84, and is measured to the base of the V2X antenna. The V2X antenna is the antenna for the V2X Radio Interface.
NTCIP_1218-543
3.5.1.1.3.5 Report Positioning Augmentation
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1609 GNSS Augmentation
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-544

If RSU is receiving geopositioning data from an external GNSS or similar geopositioning device, upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report if its position from the GNSS or similar geopositioning device is augmented with Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) corrections.
NTCIP_1218-545
3.5.1.1.3.6 Forward GNSS Data Requirements
NTCIP_1218-546

The requirements for the RSU to forward the GNSS data from an external GNSS or similar geopositioning device to another external device follows.
NTCIP_1218-547
3.5.1.1.3.6.1 Store GNSS Data Output Destination
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1659 GNSS Output Port
NTCIP_1218-1660 GNSS Output Address
NTCIP_1218-1661 GNSS Output Interface Description
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-548

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the network destination that the RSU forwards the GNSS data from an external GNSS or similar geopositioning device to. The network destination consists of the udp port number, IP address, and a text description of the interface.
2024-11-12: Kenneth Vaughn

How is the GNSS data formatted?
NTCIP_1218-549
3.5.1.1.3.6.2 Report GNSS Data Output
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1663 GNSS Data Output
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-550

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the GNSS data that is being forwarded to an external device.
NTCIP_1218-551
3.5.1.1.3.6.3 Store GNSS Data Output Interval
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1662 GNSS Output Interval
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-289 Manage RSU Location Information
NTCIP_1218-552

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the interval, in seconds, from 1 to 18,000 seconds, between transmissions containing the GNSS data to an external device via the network interface (and not across the V2X interface).
NTCIP_1218-553
3.5.1.1.4 Manage RSU Startup Function Requirements
NTCIP_1218-554

These requirements allow a transportation manager to configure which configuration file to use and what applications are to be started when the RSU is powered on or rebooted.
NTCIP_1218-555
3.5.1.1.4.1 Determine Maximum Number of Applications Supported
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1910 Maximum Applications
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-291 Manage RSU Startup Functions
NTCIP_1218-556

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of applications that can be supported on the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-557
3.5.1.1.4.2 Manage RSU Startup Functions - Applications
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1911 RSU Application Configuration Table
NTCIP_1218-1914 Application Configuration ID Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1915 Application Configuration Name
NTCIP_1218-1916 Application Configuration Startup Parame…
NTCIP_1218-1920 Application Configuration Status
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-291 Manage RSU Startup Functions
NTCIP_1218-558

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store what applications are part of the RSU's startup functions. This requirement allows the management station to specify which applications are to be started when the RSU is powered on or rebooted. Note that application data exchanges over the V2X interface are identified by PSIDs. Refer to 3.5.1.2.2.1.6.
NTCIP_1218-559
3.5.1.1.4.3 Manage RSU Startup Functions - Configuration File
Satisfied with note by:
NTCIP_1218-1834 System Configuration File
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-291 Manage RSU Startup Functions
NTCIP_1218-560

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the name of the configuration file to use as part of the RSU's startup functions. This requirement allows the RSU to be configured for different roles.
NTCIP_1218-561
3.5.1.1.4.4 Configure Startup Retries
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

Replaced by ISO 26048-1, 8.17.2.1 and 8.17.2.2
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1835 System Startup Retries
NTCIP_1218-562

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the allowable number of attempts within a user-defined period to properly reboot an RSU before the RSU enters the 'fault' operating mode. An attempt may be a result of a power up, a reboot, or a watchdog reboot. An RSU fails to properly reboot if the firmware, operating system, or drivers do not load properly during its startup. The 'fault' operating mode (e.g., safe mode) allows the RSU to only load sufficient functionality for a transportation manager to download and install the correct firmware, operating system, drivers and applications without any operational impacts. A value of 0 indicates this feature is disabled (the RSU cannot enter the 'fault' operating mode).
NTCIP_1218-563
3.5.1.1.4.5 Retrieve Startup Retry Period
2024-10-29: Kenneth Vaughn

Replaced with ISO 26048-1, 8.17.2.3
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1836 System Startup Retry Period
NTCIP_1218-564

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall retrieve the defined period, in minutes, that an RSU is allowed to attempt reboots before the RSU enters the 'fault' operating mode. The 'fault' operating mode (e.g., safe mode) allows the RSU to only load sufficient functionality for a transportation manager to download and install the correct firmware, operating system, drivers and applications without any operational impacts. The startup retry period is defined by the vendor in consideration of the period of time needed for the RSU to properly start all its required processes.
NTCIP_1218-565
3.5.1.1.5 Manage RSU Firmware Version Requirements
NTCIP_1218-566

The requirements to manage the RSU's firmware version follows.
NTCIP_1218-567
3.5.1.1.5.1 Report the RSU Firmware Version
2024-11-12: Kenneth Vaughn

Addressed by RFC 6933
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1810 RSU Firmware Version
NTCIP_1218-568

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the firmware version currently in use by the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-569
3.5.1.1.5.2 Update the RSU Firmware Version
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1209 Secure Installation Dialog
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1810 RSU Firmware Version
NTCIP_1218-1817 RSU Installation Command
NTCIP_1218-1818 RSU Installation Filename
NTCIP_1218-1819 RSU Installation Path
NTCIP_1218-1820 RSU Installation Status
NTCIP_1218-1840 System Base Directory
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-293 Manage RSU Firmware Version
NTCIP_1218-570

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall support firmware updates from an authorized source. The update process allows the transmission of the secure installation files and associated support files for the purpose of the installment of the installation files, and confirmation of a successful update of the RSU firmware.
NTCIP_1218-571
3.5.1.1.5.3 Report Firmware Update Status
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1820 RSU Installation Status
NTCIP_1218-1821 RSU Installation Status Time
NTCIP_1218-1822 RSU Installation Status Message
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-293 Manage RSU Firmware Version
NTCIP_1218-572

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the process to update the RSU's firmware, and the date and time the status was last updated. The valid values for status are: rejected, roll-backed, processing, successful, and unknown. An attempt to update the firmware may be rejected for a security reason, such as it has not been authenticated. If an attempt to update the firmware fails, the firmware should be roll-backed to the pre-update version.
NTCIP_1218-573
3.5.1.1.6 Manage Communications Lost Requirements
NTCIP_1218-574

A communications loss is defined as when a valid communications request has not been received from a management station over a user-specified period of time. The requirements to configure the RSU when communications with the management station is lost follow.
NTCIP_1218-575
3.5.1.1.6.1 Configure Short-Term Communications Loss
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1837 Short Communications Loss Time
Option group for:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-576

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store the period of time, in seconds, that communications with the management station is lost to define a short-term communications loss. The short-term communications loss is an event that may result in the RSU changing a behavior, such as to stop broadcasting time-sensitive messages (e.g., traveler information about an unplanned incident). Optionally, the RSU may also have a long-term communications loss event defined. The long-term communications loss duration is greater than the short-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-577
3.5.1.1.6.2 Configure Long-Term Communications Loss
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1838 Long Communications Loss Time
Option group for:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-578

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store the period of time, in minutes, that communications with the management station is lost to define a long-term communications loss. The long-term communications loss is an event that may result in the RSU changing a behavior, such as to stop broadcasting messages. Optionally, the RSU may also have a short-term communications loss event defined. The short-term communications loss duration should be less than the long-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-579
3.5.1.1.6.3 Configure Short-Term Communications Event for Stored Messages
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1623 Stored Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Satisfied with note by:
Notes-5 Configure Short-Term Communications Even…
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-580

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store what stored messages the RSU is to stop transmitting via the V2X interface when a short-term communications loss event occurs. The short-term communications loss event occurs when the period of time since communications was lost with the management station exceeds the short-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-581
3.5.1.1.6.4 Configure Long-Term Communications Event for Stored Messages
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1623 Stored Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Satisfied with note by:
Notes-6 Configure Long-Term Communications Event…
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-582

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store what stored messages the RSU is to stop transmitting via the V2X interface when a long-term communications loss event occurs. The long-term communications loss event occurs when the period of time since communications was lost with the management station exceeds the long-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-583
3.5.1.1.6.5 Configure Short-Term Communications Event for Immediate Forward Messages
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1630 Immediate Forward Table
NTCIP_1218-1633 Forward Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1637 Forward Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Satisfied with note by:
Notes-8 Configure Short-Term Communications Even…
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-584

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU is to stop transmitting, via the V2X interface, a received message to be forwarded when a short-term communications loss event occurs. The short-term communications loss event occurs when the period of time since communications were lost with the management station exceeds the short-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-585
3.5.1.1.6.6 Configure Long-Term Communications Event for Immediate Forward Messages
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1630 Immediate Forward Table
NTCIP_1218-1633 Forward Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1637 Forward Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Satisfied with note by:
Notes-9 Configure Long-Term Communications Event…
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-586

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU is to stop transmitting, via the V2X interface, a received message for forwarding when a long-term communications loss event occurs. The long-term communications loss event occurs when the period of time since communications was lost with the management station exceeds the long-term communications loss duration.
NTCIP_1218-587
3.5.1.1.6.7 Configure Long-Term Communications Event for Reboot
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1841 Long Communications Loss Reboot
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-295 Manage Communications Loss
NTCIP_1218-588

Upon a request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU is to reboot when a long-term communications loss event occurs. The long-term communications loss event occurs when the period of time since communications was lost with the management station exceeds the long-term communications loss duration. This requirement allows an operator to avoid a field trip to reboot the RSU in case of a network issue.
NTCIP_1218-589
3.5.1.1.7 Manage Notification Requirements
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Do we want to keep these as independent events or define as conditional triggers?

If keeping, add a requirement to use the independent notification feature defined in ISO 26048-1
NTCIP_1218-590

The requirements to configure notifications for the RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-591
3.5.1.1.7.1 Store Notification Destination Address
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete, this is not how notifications are handled in SNMPv3. See SnmpTarget and ISO26048-1.
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1825 Notification Destination Address
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-592

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the destination network address for all notifications generated by the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-593
3.5.1.1.7.2 Store Notification Destination Port
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Delete, this is not how notifications are handled in SNMPv3. See SnmpTarget and ISO26048-1.
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1826 Notification Destination Port
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-594

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the destination port number for all notifications generated by the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-595
3.5.1.1.7.3 Notification Message Requirements
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Update all requirements to refer to the configuration of Independent Notifications per ISO 26048-1 rather than "destination network address and port number"

2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Rather than defining unique, independent notifications, it may be better to define counters and similar parameters that can be configured to use the standard notification scheme or be logged, etc.
NTCIP_1218-596

The requirements for different notification messages for an RSU follow.
NTCIP_1218-597
3.5.1.1.7.3.1 Notification - Integrity Check Error - Active Message
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1876 File Integrity Check Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1892 File Integrity Check Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-390 Manage Data Integrity
NTCIP_1218-598

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of an integrity check error on a message intended to be forwarded to the V2X interface. An integrity check error indicates that the accuracy and consistency of the data in the message may be in doubt. The message may be a stored message intended to be forwarded to the V2X interface for transmission.
NTCIP_1218-599
3.5.1.1.7.3.2 Notification - Integrity Check Error - Secure Storage
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1877 Storage Integrity Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1893 Storage Integrity Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-390 Manage Data Integrity
NTCIP_1218-600

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of an integrity check error on any data parameters in secure storage. An integrity check error indicates that the accuracy and consistency of the data may be in doubt.
NTCIP_1218-601
3.5.1.1.7.3.3 Notification - Authorization Verification Error
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1878 Authorization Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1894 Authorization Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-602

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of an authorization error on any data received by the RSU via the network interface or the V2X interface. An authorization error occurs when the identity of a process or user requesting access to the RSU, its services or its data cannot be authenticated, or if a user, process or application requests a service or data for which it is not authorized.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

"The network interface" is ambiguous. It may be better to say "any electronic interface (e.g., local port, central port, V2X, etc.)"

This overlaps with the RFC 3418 authenticationFailure notification. The requirement to report requests with insufficient access rights is new, but is ambiguous (i.e., does one request containing two objects with insufficient access and one object with sufficient access result in 0, 1, or 2 notifications).

Propose replacing this with:

1. authenticationFailures notification (along with snmpEnableAuthenTraps)

2. A new ISO 26048-1 notification that reports noSuchObject and noSuchInstance errors along with the objects requested and the securityName used (i.e., this is for get operations)

3. A new ISO 26048-1 notification that reports noAccess errors along with the objects requested and the security name used (i.e., this is for set operations)

Or should we make these counters and leave the possibility that an implementation logs the issue rather than sending notifications (i.e., should all implementations be required to support notifications?)
NTCIP_1218-603
3.5.1.1.7.3.4 Notification - Signature Verification Error
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1879 Signature Verification Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1895 Signature Verification Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-388 Manage Authentication
NTCIP_1218-604

The RSU shall transmit notifications to the destination network address and port number upon detection of a signature error in the WAVE messages received by the RSU from the V2X interface.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Signature or verification error; i.e., the text suggests a "signature error", which implies an encoding error or similar whereas the title indicates a signature verification error, which could mean the same thing or perhaps implies any issue that results in signature verification failing (e.g., expired credentials). I assume the intent is the latter and the text should be updated.

We should probably clarify and update, that it is any message received (e.g., including broadcast messages) from V2X interface(s). In other words, as an international concept, these are not necessarily WAVE messages, there could be multiple radios at different frequencies, and the messages are frequently broadcasted rather than being directed at the RSU.
NTCIP_1218-605
3.5.1.1.7.3.5 Notification - Network Access Control List
2024-08-07: Kenneth Vaughn

Suggest tracing to authentication rather than availability
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1880 Access Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1896 Access Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-392 Manage Availability
NTCIP_1218-606

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of an attempt of remote network access to the RSU by an application, service, or user from a network address, port number or physical interface not permitted by the RSU's Network Access Control List or Firewall.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Should be replaced with a conditional trigger based on fdFirewallRejectedPackets with a report of the fdFirewallRejectedAddress, fdFirewallRejectedPort, and fdFirewallRejectedRuleID


Should revise to read "attempt of network access to the RSU", (i.e., "remote network" could imply the exclusion of local ports)
NTCIP_1218-607
3.5.1.1.7.3.6 Notification - Time Source Loss
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1881 Time Source Lost Message
NTCIP_1218-1897 Time Source Lost Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-608

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of the loss of valid data from the primary time source greater than a defined threshold. The threshold is defined in Sections 3.5.2.3.3 and 3.5.2.3.4.
NTCIP_1218-609
3.5.1.1.7.3.7 Notification - Time Source Mismatch
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1882 Time Source Mismatch Message
NTCIP_1218-1898 Time Source Mismatch Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-610

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of a time deviation that exceeds a defined threshold between any two time sources. The threshold is defined in Section 3.5.2.3.5.
NTCIP_1218-611
3.5.1.1.7.3.8 Notification - GNSS Anomaly
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1883 GNSS Anomaly Message
NTCIP_1218-1899 GNSS Anomaly Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-612

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of any spoofing, interference, jamming, or signal or data anomalies in the data received from a GNSS or similar geopositioning device.
NTCIP_1218-613
3.5.1.1.7.3.9 Notification - GNSS Location Deviation
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1884 GNSS Deviation Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1900 GNSS Deviation Error Details
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-614

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number upon detection of a deviation between the RSU's reference location and the geopositioning data received from a GNSS or similar geopositioning device exceeds a defined threshold. See Section 3.5.2.4.3.
NTCIP_1218-615
3.5.1.1.7.3.10 Notification - Certificate Management
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1886 Certificate Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
NTCIP_1218-1903 Certificate Error Details
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-388 Manage Authentication
NTCIP_1218-616

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number if the RSU has no usable certificates for transmission on the V2X interface, if the certificates are expired, or if the RSU is unable retrieve certificates from the Certificate Authority.
NTCIP_1218-617
3.5.1.1.7.3.11 Notification - Denial of Service
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1887 Denial of Service Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
NTCIP_1218-1904 Denial of Service Error Details
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-618

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number if the Channel Busy Ratio on a wireless channel is greater than a user-configurable threshold. The threshold is not defined by NTCIP 1218 v01.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

How is this meaningful if I do not know the ratio being used? How do I control this if I get swampped by these messages?
NTCIP_1218-619
3.5.1.1.7.3.12 Notification - Watchdog
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1888 Watchdog Error Message
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
NTCIP_1218-1905 Watchdog Error Details
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-620

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number if the watchdog process on the RSU detects a potential fault condition. The watchdog process is a health monitor process on the RSU that monitors all software processes and sets a flag when an application or process appears to be inoperative. The watchdog process may also automatically restart an application or process, or reboot the RSU in the event the watchdog determines a restart or reboot is necessary to restore "normal" operations. An RSU may have more than one watchdog process, one for the main program, and perhaps for each process or service deemed "critical" for the RSU, as determined by the RSU vendor and/or the agency operating the RSU.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Duplicates functionality of ISO 26048-1 (i.e., watchdog failure counter) coupled with notification feature
NTCIP_1218-621
3.5.1.1.7.3.13 Notification - GNSS Data
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1663 GNSS Data Output
NTCIP_1218-1885 GNSS NMEA Message
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-622

The RSU shall transmit the GNSS data received from a GNSS or similar geopositioning device to the destination network address and port number at user-defined intervals.
NTCIP_1218-623
3.5.1.1.7.3.14 Notification - Configure GNSS Data Interval
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1901 GNSS NMEA Details
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-624

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the interval, in seconds, that the RSU transmits the GNSS data received from a GNSS or similar geopositioning device to.
NTCIP_1218-625
3.5.1.1.7.3.15 Notification - Environmental
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1889 Enclosure Environment Message
NTCIP_1218-1902 Notification Alert Level
NTCIP_1218-1906 Environmental Error Details
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-364 Determine RSU Environment
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-626

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number if the RSU detects an environmental error. An environmental error is an environmental condition that may damage the RSU or affect its proper operation. Examples of environmental errors are a high internal temperature which may damage the RSU.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

This seems awfully broad and untestable. It is likely redundant with SRSA (e.g., processor temp, etc).
NTCIP_1218-627
3.5.1.1.7.3.16 Notification - Authentication Failure
Satisfied by:
rfc3418-31 authenticationFailure
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-628

The RSU shall transmit a notification to the destination network address and port number if the RSU detects an authentication error from a bad community string (mismatch).
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

community strings do not exist in SNMPv3 (and this is redundant with a similar SNMPv1 trap anyway)
NTCIP_1218-629
3.5.1.1.7.4 Store Notification Type
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
rfc3413-35 snmpNotifyEntry
rfc3413-37 snmpNotifyName
rfc3413-38 snmpNotifyTag
rfc3413-39 snmpNotifyType
rfc3413-40 snmpNotifyStorageType
rfc3413-41 snmpNotifyRowStatus
Satisfied with note by:
rfc3413-34 snmpNotifyTable
Optionally fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-630

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the notification type for each notification message generated by the RSU. The valid values are trap and inform, as defined by snmpNotifyType in RFC 3413. Inform type indicates that the RSU is expecting an acknowledgement that the notification message has been received at the destination address and port.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Redundant with ISO 26048-1 notification feature
NTCIP_1218-631
3.5.1.1.7.5 Store Notification Repeat Intervals
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1907 Notification Repeat Interval
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-632

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the minimum period of time, in seconds, required to elapse before re-transmitting a notification message that has not been acknowledged. This requirement is only applicable if the notification message is an inform type, as defined by snmpNotifyType in RFC 3413.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Redundant
NTCIP_1218-633
3.5.1.1.7.6 Store Notification Retries
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1908 Notification Maximum Retransmission Retr…
Conditionally meets:
NTCIP_1218-297 Manage Notifications
NTCIP_1218-634

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the maximum number of attempts the RSU is to retransmit a notification message to the destination network address and port number. This requirement is only applicable if the notification message is an inform type, as defined by snmpNotifyType in RFC 3413.
2024-07-22: Kenneth Vaughn

Redundant
NTCIP_1218-635

NTCIP_1218-641
3.5.1.2.1.2 Configure Ethernet Ports
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

This name of this requirement talks about configuring an Ethernet port (Data Link layer) but in fact focuses on network layer aspects, which is confusing. Further, the text refers to configuring "an Ethernet port" but the referenced objects are scalar, which limits all Ethernet ports to the same configuration or only allows configuration of a single Ethernet port.

Clarify the requirement and title and revise the MIB structure into a table if needed.
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1842 RSU Host Network Address Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1843 RSU Host Net Mask Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1844 RSU Host Gateway Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1845 RSU Host Domain Name Server Parameter
NTCIP_1218-1846 RSU Host DHCP Enable Parameter
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-301 Manage a Network Interface
NTCIP_1218-642

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the network address, gateway address, subnet mask, domain name server address, and whether DHCP is enabled for an Ethernet port on the RSU.

NTCIP_1218-654
3.5.1.2.2.1.3 Delete a Stored Message
2024-08-09: Kenneth Vaughn

Follow standard rules for table traceability throughout (i.e., do not refer to the table, entry, or index because they should be defined as not-accessible, although the index is ~allowed~ to be read-only for backwards compatibility but should still not be a part of a trace)

NTCIP_1218-658
3.5.1.2.2.1.5 Store a Message Type [Deprecated]
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1621 Stored Message Payload
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-305 Manage Stored Messages
NTCIP_1218-659

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the message type of a stored message. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735.
NTCIP_1218-660

Note: This requirement was deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A. This requirement traced to an object definition, rsuMsgRepeatPayload, that is proposed to be deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A because the payload size was increased to support C-V2X communications (See 5.4.2.12 rsuMsgRepeatPayload2). There is no separate object that defines the message id type, the message type can be found within the payload of the message. There was previously an expectation that the object would indicate the message type, but it involved parsing the payload.
NTCIP_1218-661

NTCIP_1218-307 Manage Stored Messages for Transmission
NTCIP_1218-664

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall delete all stored messages from the RSU's memory. This requirement allows a transportation manager to clear all stored messages prior to field installation or for testing purposes.
NTCIP_1218-665

NTCIP_1218-666

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the user priority assigned to a stored message. For a V2X radio, the user priority is an integer value and is defined in IEEE 1609.3.

NTCIP_1218-668

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the time interval, in milliseconds, between successive transmissions that a stored message is to be transmitted.
NTCIP_1218-669
3.5.1.2.2.1.10 Store a Message's Transmission Channel
2024-10-16: Kenneth Vaughn

allowing different channels to be specified for different rows (store and repeat/forward message) could create conflict.  This isn’t a new item for this version of the proposed standard.  Obviously, each vendor will have to handle any such configuration items according to their best judgement, but given the minimal spectrum allocated for RSU/OBU communications in the US and the need for most C-V2X/PC5 applications to use a 20 MHz channel, it may be worthwhile to consider tightening the guidelines for channel usage across the different message types. (NTCIPv01.44b-15)
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1617 Stored Message Transmission Channel
NTCIP_1218-1623 Stored Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-307 Manage Stored Messages for Transmission
NTCIP_1218-670

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the transmission channel, as defined by the appropriate regulatory domain, a stored message is to be transmitted on. The valid values for the transmission channel are 0 to 255.
NTCIP_1218-671

Note: For radios using IEEE 802.11, the transmission channel number is defined by IEEE 802.11. For PC5 radios, the equivalent transmission channel number is defined in Table 7, where EARFCN is the E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number.
NTCIP_1218-673

Channel Number (See IEEE 802.11)

Center Frequency (MHz)

Bandwidth

EARFCN (3GPP Channel Number)

180

5900

10 MHz

54990

182

5910

10 MHz

55090

184

5920

10 MHz

55190

181

5905

20 MHz

55040

183

5915

20 MHz

55140
NTCIP_1218-679

Note: SAE points to a 10MHz channel.
NTCIP_1218-680

Figure 5 is a graphical depiction of the IEEE 802.11 channel mappings.
NTCIP_1218-681

NTCIP_1218-683

Note: In the United States at the time of publication, the transmission channel is a value of 180, and a value of 183.

NTCIP_1218-688
3.5.1.2.2.1.13 Store if a Message is to be Signed
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1623 Stored Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Satisfied with note by:
Notes-7 Store if a Message is to be Signed
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-307 Manage Stored Messages for Transmission
NTCIP_1218-689

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store if the payload of the stored message is to be signed prior to forwarding the message for transmission to the V2X wireless interface. A RSU has three options for signing the payload of a stored message: sign, which is to sign and wrap the message into an appropriate security header; do-not-sign, which still wraps the message into a security header but without signing the message; and bypass, which transmits the payload "as-is" without even wrapping the message into a security header. This last option assumes that the transmitter of the payload already put the appropriate security header into the payload.
NTCIP_1218-690
3.5.1.2.2.1.14 Store a Message V2
Implemented with:
NTCIP_1218-1215 Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dyn…
Satisfied by:
NTCIP_1218-1612 Store and Repeat Table
NTCIP_1218-1615 Stored Message Index
NTCIP_1218-1616 Stored Message PSID
NTCIP_1218-1617 Stored Message Transmission Channel
NTCIP_1218-1618 Stored Message Transmission Interval
NTCIP_1218-1623 Stored Message Status
NTCIP_1218-1626 Stored Message Payload2
NTCIP_1218-1849 Consistency Check Verify Error Parameter
Fulfills:
NTCIP_1218-305 Manage Stored Messages
NTCIP_1218-691

Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store a message for future transmission.
NTCIP_1218-692

Note: This previously available requirement to store a message has been deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A. This replacement was made because the payload size was increased to support LTE-V2X communications. The previously available requirement can be found in 3.5.1.2.2.1.2. See Annex D.1.1 for more information regarding this change from v01 to v01A of NTCIP 1218.
NTCIP_1218-693

NTCIP_1218-696
